reviewText: Apple makes good looking, easy to use products, but God help you if your products don't work. Don't think this is a one off "damaged in shipment" rant because mine worked fine for a few months and then exhibited a problem many others are writing about online.Their support makes calling a 3 hour support line in India seem like a pleasant solution. Because in this case after you go through your call and endless steps the problems are often resolved. Apple gives you advice that doesn't work, doesn't give you advice that does which they should know and then at some point throws up their hands and says "sorry screw you" even though you've invested money for years in their products like content that is now useless to you. This happened to my entire iTunes music library as well. I kept at it but had I not I would have been out thousands of dollars I spent. Apple support cut me loose to my own devices. (no pun intended)Anyway back to Apple TV.This Apple TV worked for months and then recently it started taking content like movies 2+ hours to load. I also have Netflix, Youtube, Amazon and Hulu Plus on my Smart TV and none of them have problems so I know it's not a network issue.I searched the net for hours trying to find out what's going on. It turns out users all over the world are having this problem as well. 100's of pages of discussion and still no resolution is forth coming nor has apple addressed this issue. They have a short support page on it that according to what I've read has helped absolutely no one. It's clear it's still a problem and as of to date silence from apple with the exception that "yes some apple tv's will be replaced for free". Sadly my Apple TV serial number is not one of the ones eligable? Why not? I purchased it very recently.For various products including Apple TV I've contacted customer support and 20 to 30 emails later being constantly shuffled around they *still* don't know what I'm talking about. I am very fluent in english, tend to express myself well and have spent years engineering devices like Apple TV so the problem is not on my end. I was also friendly and patient.Recently it started working again but it's a gamble. Say you have a movie night planned with your sweetheart and friends and nothing plays for you that day? It's not a gamble with any other streaming service like Netflix, but it is with Apple. Buying an Apple product means you are at the mercy of your own technical expertise and if I as a former hardware designer and former software designer with a degree in physics can't figure it out, then it's generally not suitable for the average consumer.Yes of course I reset the box, downloaded firmware updates and reset the box, reset my modem, reset my router, updated the firmware on my router, checked all my router settings, did an internet speed check, reset network configurations, spent hours researching on the net, etc. I would say stick with other streaming services but the problem is Netflix and Hulu don't have the large selection that Apple does.One thing you can do is download the entire movie while you're at work onto your laptop hard drive and watch it on your laptop. Then you are guaranteed that you will be able to watch the movie or tv show when you want it. Which would obviate the necessity of buying this box.Or if being randomly disappointed when the screen says "3 hours until movie is ready to watch" and you don't mind that by all means go ahead and buy the product but don't expect support. And of course yours could be one of the many boxes that is never affected by this problem, but how would you know?
summary: 5 Stars for Potential, 1 Star for Extremely Poor Apple Support

reviewText: I don't own one of these but I have several friends who do, and I am familiar with them.  They are OK for what the do, and they do work as specified right down to that comfortable feel Apple kool-aide drinkers get with Apple products (I'm not an Apple hater, I have an iPad3 and and iPod Touch).  If this were the only option out there it would be fine, and for $99 it might even be attractive.  However, for under $130 you can get a BluRay player that will allow you to connect with many more video sources and also allow you the option to play just about any kind of disk video media you happen to have around.  I have a $129 (street) player manufactured by Sony and I have yet to exhaust the number of video sources it offers in its standard implementation.  For example, I get Yahoo, Netflis, Vudu, Crackle, Hulu +. amd about 15 other sources (many of them offering free content).  My player plays any disk I insert into it so it doubles as a DVD player, a CD player and a SDHD media player.  It also has connected to each of the 6 WiFi routers I connected to.  So, for $30 the choice was very clear to me.  The Apple TV source media availability is much inferior to my BluRay player and it has no where the versatility in that it can't play disks.  If they offered it at about the $50 price point it might become attractive to some people who have assessed their options.  However, for me to consider one, they would have to price it at about $20, which still would give Apple a fine return on the hardware and they still get to sell you iTunes!

My "newest" apple tv is a big let down. I am a many years long apple user, fan, advocate, but this ATV (along with iCloud) has me feeling like I've been pushed aside in the interests of fast selling. I say this because: The ATV is dependent upon iTunes. The key here is "tunes." I have lots of video I created with Apple software and most of it, by default, is in my Movies folder. Also, iPhoto and iMovie and Quicktime all are image or video oriented. Why are we using a music software like iTunes. Because it sets you up to buy, buy, buy stuff. My new apple tv shows me icons for Movies and TV but everything in those categories is for purchase. The only way to access my movies or any video I have, is convert it to a iTunes (very limited) format; import it into iTunes, then access it via the Computer icon. But wait, I have to first set up Home Sharing which my Apple MacBook Pro will not do because it rejects my Apple user id (their screw-up, not mine. They have a very old email address of mine which they simple won't let go of).Also...very significant, this new Apple TV 1080p will not play out at better then 720p on both my HDTVs. Why, because, it is p not i. (Google it). In short, it is outputting at a higher or better resolution (p). Now, in most products, if it has greater capabilities than your existing equipment, it usually will automatically play down to that level. I assumed (my big mistake) that since my HDTVs are and do play at 1080i, the apple tv would as well. Wrong.It's a real pain. I can-NOT get to the greatest amount of all the video I have on my three Macs and multiple external hard drives. Unless I convert everything and put it into iTunes. I never understood when people said iTunes was bloated. Now I understand.  (*The cloud thing, well, unless I move up to apple's newest operating system, or get mobile devices I don't want, I can no longer use what I have been paying apple $100 a year for, for the past six or more years.) Waa-waa. Blah, blah. Sorry about the rant. I'm so disappointed with Apple and this ATV.
Too many bugs, does not work seamlessly like other apple products; I have an apple I everything and this is my only disappointment

I admit that when I first purchased the Apple TV just over a year ago I was extremely happy with the product.  It worked flawlessly - AT FIRST.  AirPlay was fantastic (that still works) - had no problems streaming Netflix - was easily able to Home Share and stream music and movies from my account - then, something changed.  I updated the software - everything went downhill from there.  Cannot stream from my iTunes account (home share) which is initially why I purchased the Apple TV (says I need to turn homesharing on - it's on! - tried everything to get it to work, but it won't).  Next, Netflix stalls.  Doesn't stream as it used to - flawlessly.  Airplay still works, but everything I bought the Apple TV and loved the Apple TV for no longer functions and with each update I hope the issue is fixed, but three updates later - nadda.  Apple Support isn't an option because I won't pay for it.  It should be free. Forums echo similar concerns that I've expressed.  I ended up purchasing a Roku and couldn't be happier.  Hasn't failed me yet - works perfectly - so much so that I bought another (really, for the price of the Apple TV you can get 2 Rokus).  My Apple TV is a useless paperweight which is disheartening.  I am a HUGE Apple fan - own iPads, iPhones, etc.  Love them - but I cannot endorse this product until Apple makes some serious improvements.  On this one - Roku wins hands down!!

The only reason this product has 1 star is because I had to put something.This product is horrible.  I tried to rent a movie thru i-tunes.  It was going to take over 2 hours to download the movie.  I didn't want to wait that long, so let the program run overnight.  The next evening, I went to watch the movie and had to download it again.  Over 2 hours (on the lowest resolution) I am not going thru this again.  It looks like apple ripped me off for the 3.99 or whatever the movie price was.Other options are Hulu Plus and Netflix (pay services).  I was previously dissappointed in Netflix and cancelled my account.  I have not tried Hulu Plus yet.The only positive aspect:  Using the "mirror" function on my ipad and iphone worked well.  You can easily stream movies from your ipad to the apple tv wirelessly if you have them loaded on your ipad.Save your money, go to redbox or just stream movies from your laptop and connect to your TV via HDMI.I feel ripped off.

reviewText: I have been an apple fan boy for a few years. Everything, my work computer is an Macbook pro, personal is an Air, Ipad 2, iphone 4sm wife has an iphone 4. So when I decided to upgrade my ROKU (only 720P) I went right to the apple store and bought two Apple TV's. Man I was stoked thinking how cool it would be to share my screen on my apple tv, listen to my itunes on my Apple TV and even though I am a Prime member - itunes movies will work right sure they cost a buck more than Amazon - but its an apple right.Boy was I wrong.My macbooks were both refurbs so even though they are less than a year old running the newest OS I cannot share my screen on my Apple TV - only macbooks purchased in the past year can do that. The guy at the store told me no pandora, hbo go or Amazon Prime - but the trick was to run them on the ipad and screen share on the apple TV. Fat chance - apple blocks those sites.As for itunes and listening to music - only if you spend $25 a year to push your music to the cloud and renting Videos from itunes - HAThere is a bug that everyone on the apple site is complaining about which cause the movie to crash every 2-20 minutes. So a 2 hour movie requires 30-45 resets.Steve Jobs is dead and so is Apple - new Roku on the way, next phone will be a Samsung and what is all this I hear about Windows 8?

Neither free of paid for.Can't watch Fox, ABC, NBC, or any other free over the web content.Shows that you can watch for free on you notebook you have to pay to view on ATV3.Suggestions, get an old used ATV2 and jailbrake it or wait until it has been jailbroken.After purchasing the ATV3 I went and made a myth box it does what I want.The ATV3 was a said let down after using the ATV1.

reviewText: The cable that turns this from an "Apple Paperweight" into an "Apple TV," is not included.  I opened the box when I first got it and was like, "Oh what the hell, man?"But don't worry, in lieu of functionality, you'll get - not one - but two Apple stickers as a consolation prize.  I'm 30-years-old, I don't grade essays written by children, and I don't own a skateboard... what the hell do I need stickers for?  They are completely and utterly useless.You know what would be useful??  THE CABLE THAT CONNECTS THIS TO THE TV!!  I'd go to the Apple Store to complain, but no one likes being around all those horn rimmed glasses. I actually read a book the night I got this.  Not a whole book - just, like, 4 chapters or whatever.  But still - I actually cracked open a hardback that evening because I couldn't watch the 21 episodes of Robot Chicken that I downloaded the night before.  Such a load of crap.

reviewText: I purchased my first Apple TV on Christmas 2012.  It was fantastic.  I plugged it in, entered my account, made sure iTunes was running on my PC and voila! it worked flawlessly.My kids and I watched movies over the entire Christmas vacation.  It was great.  So much so, I purchased a second Apple TV for my bedroom.  Awesome!Then about 4 months ago, Apple updated my box and since then it won't connect to my iTunes account on my PC.  The only thing they are good for is watching ONLY movies I have purchased through iTunes.  All of my home videos of my kids playing and opening presents are no longer available.I did some checking and found that there are many other people encountering the same thing.  When I contacted Apple about my problem, they had me run through a battery of registry updates, network protocol changes, and constant rebooting and restarting and restoring.  Nothing works.So, I am now at a loss.  I really want to love this thing, but it has failed me miserably.  I only hope yours works.  Because, when they work, they are fantastic.
summary: I used to love my Apple TV

reviewText: About me, I'm a tech guy with 30 years experience. Over the past 2 years I have heavily invested in the Apple Eco System. I have IPods, an iPad 2, a 2012 Mac Mini, and now Apple TV (newest version). It's been well stated that there is not a lot available for content outside of the Apple Eco System as compared to Roku, for example.I've hardwired the ethernet connection to my router from the Apple TV, as suggested, to avoid overloading my wireless capability at home.I'm running the latest version of the OS on the Apple TV, Mirroring my Mountain Lion and Ipad screens is very handy.I've updated my review and added a 4th star because the 'wired ethernet causing content load failure' issue has been addressed. The device needs to have more content available and have it available from the Itunes store. That's the only drawback at this point that I see, and it costs 1 star...I have seen one 'bug' in the current version of the software. Loading select Vimeo content caused an error message stating that the content wouldn't load because my TV didn't support the 'HDMC' protocol (an encryption protocol used by newer HDMI devices). Recommended fix was replugging my Apple TV into the TV. That didn't work. Cold booting the Apple TV did fix the issue.As others have stated, this is a no brainer if you already have Apple products, especially newer ones. If you don't have Apple products, then unfortunately at this time, I could not recommend this product to you, it simply wouldn't have the value per the cost to you... That's the bottom line.
summary: First Impressions - Needs more Content but Great for Up to Date Apple Users

reviewText: Adding Apple TV to our own changed everything the same way adding a TIVO back in the day did.  I love having my movies and tv shoes at my finger tips. I have a child and having his movies all there without having to fumble with finding, keeping track of, or changing DVDs is really great

Apple Tv is awsome you are able to watch netflex right off of it . You can access your itunes account off of it . you can stream any songs or videos or pictures off of your other Apple products off of this Apple Tv. I would reccomend this product to anyone that  has quite a few Apple products.

As a bit of background, there are 4 iPads, 2 iPhones, 2 iPod Touches, and a Mac Mini in my house. Because of all the iOS devices around my house and because all my media is already in iTunes on the Mac Mini. Anyway, because of all this, I made the decision to purchase the Apple TV instead of a Roku that I was looking at and so far I am very pleased. The apple TV connects easily to my itunes library and plays all of my movies and music. Using Airplay to stream music and videos off of my assorted ios devices is very nice also. Netflix and Hulu both work well on the Apple TV and there are many other "Channels" such as sports, and childrens programming that will appeal to others.In summary, if you already have your media in itunes or have ios devices this is a very good choice for a streaming device.
summary: Very good if you have iOS devices

reviewText: As a home and business custom audio visual integrator, we've installed more Apple TVs in our systems than any other AV product on the market. The best feature on the Apple TV is Airplay with Video. With airplay, you can wirelessly stream audio and video from anywhere on the WiFi network. It's so easy to use and allows anyone with an Apple device (iPad, iPhone, Macbook) to stream their content without having to download software, drivers or connect external dongles.With an Apple TV connected to an AV receiver and/or a nice HDTV, the audio and video quality are top notch. The built in apps like Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, Vimeo and 1000s of internet radio stations provide great entertainment all in High Definition. However, if it's not on the Apple TV, then you can use Airplay to view and listen to whatever app from your iPhone etc.From a business usage standpoint, the ability to wirelessly stream slideshow or video presentations to any attached video display makes the Apple TV an inexpensive digital signage solution. The possibilities are truly limitless.PROS: Super easy to use and works seamlessly with other apple products. High quality audio and video experience. Airplay is awesome.CONS: Occasional loss of network connection can confuse some users but simply powering off and then back on will fix it. Lack of RCA audio outputs can be limiting for people with older AV equipment.
summary: One of the best little Apple products around

reviewText: At first it was really complicated to figure out the whole apple tv, even its overall function, and was very offended to realize the herding attempt by apple /itunes as an only option to buy movies or music.........that was the negative.There is everything positive to say when it comes to 1080p. I have a vizio 42 inch hdtv with apps and ipad 2, iphone4 as my phone.........the apple tv is awesome. And that is all inclusive. Works grate every day, flip on master switch at plug in every morning and comes on everytime. The HD, is really amazng and with all items mentioned, the apple tv has the best filter for watching stuff thru. I highly recommend the rocketfish ultra thin hdmi cable for $20, really amazing picture. The sound filter in the apple tv is also the best.It has a very sleek remote control , the apple tv is like a control panel for all your needs, music movies , netflix, are the ones I use everyday. The kool thing with the wifi is I can have my ipad and walk around the house with the ipad camera on and it will mirror on the tv. Same with video. The mirroring option is awesome. I tend to just watch things thru the apple tv rather than watch it on my ipad, and mirror to my hdtv, the filter on the apple tv makes it come in clearer picture and sound and puts everything into full 1080p format.I highly recomend is product. Well worth the hundred bucks. Comes in a nice apple box. Top notch. Besides my tv can literally carry all my entertainment needs in a backpack.............I HAVE ARRIVED.And the telefunken stand for the ipad, with all this is a sweet setup that I will have a long time. Forever.The one really kool thing is the HD movies on itunes come in so real with this setup. My neigbor sed wow, it looks so real. And thats the plus of buying movies from itunes. The quality is awesome.

At less than a hundred bucks, I decided to push the buy button after thinking about it for a couple of generational iterations. I watch a lot of TV, but seldom sports programming. I don't often rent a movie and certainly don't buy or collect DVDs, don't go to the theater often. So why do I even need this? I don't. The Apple TV is a Wi-Fi connected gateway to other web portals like Netflix, Hulu Plus, Go HBO, and Apple store most of which seem to require rental fees or paid subscriptions to get content. So beyond the hundred bucks you pay for this Wi-Fi peripheral you have to really want the content to pay extra to these providers in addition to already having working, Wi-Fi and cable or other internet connection services (which are utility subscriptions as well). Can you tell I am not a fan of the subscription payment model? Anyway, Apple TV will allow me to stream iTunes music content from my 2007 model iMac to my music system on a different floor of my home. The iMac has to be awake and iTunes running, however. Also useful, I can mirror my iPad 2 (won't work with the iPad1) and control Apple TV from it using Apple Remote app, and some apps and web sites can access Apple TV directly from the iPad. I can also display anything in my photo library on the iMac or iPad on the HDTV screen and associated surround sound system. Video and display mirroring from the iMac is limited to models 2011 and newer, very sad, but I knew that going in. I found it desirable to bump my cable internet speed from 1.5 Mbs (that's bits not bytes, by the way) to 5 Mbs another $5/mo, since some trailers and other content took a long time to load. This helped, but I think I would need even faster and more costly speed for some streaming HD content to be viewed without breaks. There is a lot of nickle and dime (read $5 and $10) added costs to getting the most out of this device. That sticks in the craw of this thrifty but honest reviewer.
Can't believe I didn't one of these sooner. Great upgrade and plenty of apps. The airplay function from my Iphone puts everything else I need on the big screen.

Excellent product.  Ditched the expensive cable bills and started steaming content from netflix, hulu, etc. product works awesome.  Small, discrete, in line with the top notch quality you expect from apple products. I DO wish apple and amazon would stop the feuding and exclusivity rights war to their content, however, as I cannot stream ANY amazon prime content through this and that (quite frankly) sucks.  I'd have to reccommend roku if that is your desire ( and I  can only go by the feedback I've read as I do not own one) as I understand yo can stream ANYTHING through them.  If you want an awesome product and do not care about streaming amazon prime content....buy this & you will not be disappointed. 4* rating due to inability to stream amazon content , otherwise would be a 5* product.
summary: Awesome but cannot stream amazon prime

reviewText: First I must admit that I support apple products fully and because I do my products work together better than most. We have 3 Mac computers, an apple extreme, 2 iPods, iPads and only iPhones, there is no droid products and the only Microsoft product is loaded on a Mac computer. This Apple TV works flawlessly with the other products and streams more beautifully than our hd cable does. There are limitations though. We purchase music and video from amazon as well as having a prime membership that forces us to watch prime video through another resource (ps3) while we were once able to stream through airplay there have been limitations created that unable both audio and video to seamlessly stream in unison. There has been additions made to the channels that are very helpful. HBO and espn to go are great additions that expand viewing options exponentially and also alleviate DVR needs for me. I would give 5 stars if amazon purchased products worked just as iTunes products do, but unfortunately they do not.

Gets the TV signal from MacAir router to the TV perfectly, great product.As an aside, I tried twice to purchase this product from the Apple web site but even eith a phone call was unsuccessful. Purchased it on Amazon with no hassle and at a slightly better price. I'm sure that doesn't surprise any Amazon shoppers.
Good price.  Mirrors my Mac laptop easily. Got my mom hooked on Netflix.  What else could you want?  THe built-in Menu doesn't offer Amazon streaming, but the easy mirroring compensates for that.

Got this about a week ago and am a bit disappointed with the content, there isn't that much of it.  Since you can watch Netflix and Hulu on just about anything these days, DO NOT BUY IT FOR THAT.  The best part by far is having your iTunes library available through your TV and the ability to use AirPlay to project your iPhone, iPad, and Mac screen to the TV Screen.You're basically paying $95 to listen to your music through your TV (and I have surround sound so i admit my music sounds amazing when I'm using the treadmill) and project images to your TV wirelessly.  Some say its worth it, some say its not.  All a matter of opinion, I think think its nice to have, but I wouldn't buy it again.  This thing would be awesome to receive as a gift.If you want more content options, like news, HBO GO, sports, things of that nature, go with the Roku HD.  If you want to project images from your apple device to your TV (which is very nice at times) go with this.This product seems like a slam dunk 3-star review to me.

Great TV accessory for $95... My two favorite features: 1. With OSX 10.9 (Maverick) you can set up your big screen as a wireless second display. 2. If you subscribe to HBO through your cable/satellite provider, you can access a huge library of HBO movies and series through the Apple TV.

Great way to access a ton of content... It's super cheap, and you have easy access to Netflix, Youtube, and other content that you can rent or buy from Apple.  It's a no brainer, and also a good step in the effort to get rid of cable.

Have to say that this is quite a clever box of tricks. Before purchasing, I did a lot of research including Apple forums and other instant streaming devices such as Roku. In the end, it is about personal choices and what works for you. I should also state that although I have an iPhone and the wife has an iPad, we are not committed to Apple products we have to have no matter what. Having said that, I DO like the minimalist styling of both the unit and its remote.The ATV3 is Apple's 3rd version and besides a few tweaks at previous bugs, the essential difference between this version and the previous ATV2, is that this one supports 1080p HD whereas ATV2 was restricted to a max of 720p. To some that matters, but I personally cannot detect the difference from my sofa! Also, when I checked where it was available to buy, the best deal was on Amazon itself for $88! Free shipping and no sales tax, too. Normal retail is $99 plus tax and the 3-4 days wait wasn't a problem either.The set-up was straighforward. Yes, you could follow the booklet that came with it but all you needed, was the instructions on the screen and you were up and running. You can have it set up wirelessly (WiFi, with a router) or an Ethernet cable (wired). My specific set up was I have a NETGEAR dual band WiFi router in the office next door that provides a wifi hotspot for the wife's iPad and my iPhone (when not using Verizon's 4G network). This particular router stated that it was designed for medium to large homes, several devices simultaneously being used and that it supported streaming HD video. My 7 year-old TV is also capable of 1080p HD res.The box comes with the small, black ATV, a power cord and the Apple remote. You WILL also need a HDMI cable to connect it to your TV, if you don't already have one. You don't need to buy a state-of-the art one with gold plating that'll set you back up to $50; they are available for as little as $20 at Radio Shack or Fry's. Mine was one left by my TV cable company when I switched to using a CableCard instead of using one of their bulky box tops.Had the ATV for a few months now and I'm still learning what you can do with it! It's a work in progress. I would highly recommend getting a book on this device, especially one that includes trouble-shooting. There is one available on this site and it DOES cover the ATV3. Having this companion, I found, is very useful and not too technical following each chapter, depending what it is you're looking for.All in all, I have no regrets in buying this product as I already had the other devices with which it runs. About my only criticism is that the library content on say, Netflix, is not as wide as on the regular mail-in DVD. If you do a search on either, you are more likely to find the physical DVD format available as the same movie as instant streaming. Apple's good but even it and iTunes are not 100% perfect! Maybe they will add more content and encourage more consumers. Already other companies are giving them a good run for their money and there's nothing like healthy competition to get a company to give the consumers what they want, rather than what they think they need!!.......

How have I gone this long without Apple TV? It's so wonderful. We have one for the spare bedroom/library and it's great for Netflix and Hulu. PLUS, I absolutely adore the whole remote-on-the-phone feature. It's also really easy to set up so if I want to switch rooms I can easily move the device. To be honest, I'll probably end up buying myself a second and another as a gift for my parents.
summary: How did I go this long without this?

reviewText: I am a big fan of Apple TV.It's an amazing device for anyone who loves high quality video content.You can absolutely choose whatever you want to watch, anytime you want to watch it.Say good by to your cable tv providers and get ready to build your own tv programming.Choosing from great movies to tv shows.And for those of you who live in Brazil, there is anything like this!!!Stop depending on Net, TVA, SKY, with their lame programming.In addition, the airplay is awesome. You are able to stream anything to your tv or receiver from your apple devices.It's a must have!!!

I bought an Apple TV to replace my Roku device on my family's main TV. I've had a Roku HD for the past year and a half which I've since moved to another TV. The Apple TV has Netflix and Hulu Plus on it which is what my family uses 99% of the time. Roku has more channels, but I rarely watched them. I do like having Spotify on the Roku, but with AirPlay I can easily run Spotify on my iPad and mirror it to my TV/sound system. I think this device is excellent for what it does. My only complaint with the Roku was that it was flaky and I had to reset it frequently. Whether that was the device itself or the software running the channel I don't know. Hopefully it's better with the newer Roku devices. I will still use my Roku on another TV. I also have most of my media in iTunes. If you have a Mac and/or several iOS devices then an Apple TV is worth consideration over Roku. I couldn't be happier with it. My kids enjoy AirPlay because one can play on the iPad while the others watch it on the TV. That solved the problem with my oldest son getting irritated by his younger brothers crowding around him to watch him play on the iPad.In summary, I think both Apple TV and Roku are capable devices. Having other Apple devices in the home was the deciding factor in purchasing an Apple TV for my family. If you don't have other Apple devices then Roku is likely a better choice.

I bought the Apple TV chiefly so I could watch movies off my ipad. The setup was very easy. The picture quality and sound are very good. However, I was just a little annoyed to find out Apple blocks Amazon movies from being played on the Apple TV. Big brother at it again. If Apple is so good, why bother blocking the competition? I still can watch other video on it though. Without the ability to watch Amazon videos, I wouldn't recommend it though. Mirroring from your ipad is nice to have, but as other reviewers have pointed out, there are better solutions out there than Apple TV.
summary: Nice to have, but limited in what it can do

reviewText: I bought this to use with my flat screen television, to watch Netflix primarily. And to mirror my iPad on a larger monitor. It works fine for both. It was quite easy to set up, and using the remote is pretty intuitive. I didn't need any directions.

I can't get super HD with Netflix or Vimeo... I have a Sony Blu-ray Player with Wifi and the quality is noticeably better. As much as I really really want to use the Apple, cause it's my new toy, I can't stand the inferior picture quality... The interface is nice... The remote is cool (I think it's drilled out of a solid piece of aluminum)  It's small and yatta yatta.... The mirroring is a bit slow.... maybe it's my router though? I do have 802n however...  I dunno.... I'd be so much happier if the friggin thing streamed HD. I'm so surprised Apple put out such a piece of crap.  I do have faith that they'll fix it some day...  People notice and aren't happy [...]
summary: Won't stream super HD right now. Apple Please fix!

reviewText: I don't usually give 5 stars to anything, and I would give this a 4.5 if that was an option.  It was a little confusing to figure out the mirroring of my Ipad as it wasn't discussed in the set up manual at all.  Once you make sure the settings are appropriate on the apple tv -AirPlay(that part was easy).  Go to your Ipad, double click on the home button to where all your open apps show up on the bar at the bottom.  Drag to the right (which takes you to the screen to the left) where the music setting are and there is a button that has a square with a triangle in the middle of it, you have to activate the mirroring on your ipad to connect with the airplay on the apple tv. Here are the instructions from Apple.  [...]My only other beef is that my computer with Itunes must be up and running in order for the apple tv to stream my movies personal movies (not movies that I have purchased from ITunes) even though they have been moved into my itunes on the computer.  So, when I am away with the computer, no one can watch our personal movies on apple tv.  The primary reason I bought Apple TV as opposed to some other player was that I could wirelessly view the screen of my Ipad on the TV.

If you don't have one, get one. I have an iPhone, iPod touch, Mac Book Pro, and an iPad. So naturally I had to get an Apple TV. By far one of my best investments. You can literally throw a video, picture, or song onto the big screen from any of your other devices. It's great when friends and family are over to be able to do so.
summary: A must have for Apple Users

reviewText: If you have an Ipad, Macbook, or other Apple device with AirPlay, you simply have to have this connected to your network and TV.  Being able to display what I'm looking at on my Ipad is worth the $100 by itself.  HBOGo, Cinemax apps work flawlessly going from my Ipad to my AppleTV.  Works just as good with my Macbook Pro and Imac.  COULD NOT BE HAPPIER WITH THIS PURCHASE.

If you have an iTunes account and some other Apple products in your home, this item is almost a necessity.Setup is very simple, plug in the power cord and connect an HDMI cable to the TV. Viola! Done! The operating system on the AppleTV is intuitive and simple to navigate. It ties directly into your home network and your iTunes account. Anything you have purchased via iTunes can be accessed on the AppleTV.Additionally, if you have an Apple iPad, iPhone or Computer, you can utilize the Mirroring or AirPlay functionality of the AppleTV. Mirroring allows you to share the screen of your device on your TV. For example, you should display the screen of your iPad on the TV screen. So if you were showing photos to family of a recent trip, you could show them on the TV rather than people needing to gather around your computer or iPad. Keep in mind that Mirroring and Airplay on works with Apple devices.The AppleTV also has various Apps built into it. You can access your Netflix account, HBO GO, and other items from Sporting Leagues like the MLB.As a bit of a caveat. If connecting multiple AppleTV devices in your house or if you happen to have other iPad/iPhone devises in your house, be cautious of what you're streaming and sending to an AppleTV. I recently heard of a story where a young man was watching some rather "adult" oriented material and didn't realize he was streaming the sound to the AppleTV in his parents TV room. Made for a rather interesting Christmas.
summary: AppleTV a must for any Apple Home

reviewText: I gave 4 of these for christmas presents this year and everyone returned them and got a Chromecast.  The reason was because they couldn't use Amazon Prime with them easily.  There are ways to watch Prime through the Apple TV but its a hassle and no one wants to jump through hoops to watch a movie.  If you don't have Amazon Prime it works great.

I got this to mirror my iPad on an hdtv.  Wow!  Really impressed.  I did have to reboot my iPad in order for the airplay icon to appear but no problems afterwards.  Sure there's a lot of fee based content here but since I cut cable years ago I wanted to be able to stream stuff off all my apple devices and home computer onto the TV.  Easy peasy.Now if we can only get Amazon Instant Videos app to become airplay compliant.........
I have one in my living room and bedroom. Love how well it streams my media. Zero bad things to say about this.

I have to admit I have become an apple junkie and this is the latest edition to my apple toys.Here are the Pros:- Easy enough to install. You need a longer hdmi cable, be warned.- Works well with streaming movies and gives you the option to stream Netflix and Hulu which is pretty nice of Apple, considering it's a much cheaper way to watch movies than through Itunes.- When you do buy a movie through Itunes, the quality is wonderful. My husband pays the Verizon Fios bill, so we take turns as to who pays for the movie on demand. Wish Apple would lower their movie rental prices to compete with Redbox- Great for streaming your iPad or IMac onto your TV screen.- There are three different speeds to fast forward and backwards. Again, you would need to read the instructions to know about it.Here are the Cons:- The remote is not self explanatory and you need to read the instructions. I would have preferred to see a button on the remote which was marked "Select" instead of just a round silver button within a black circle with arrows pointing North, West, South and East. You need to figure out what that means. For non-techy people, the remote will be an issue.- To go backwards, you need to click the menu button.- To play, if you press the silver buttonBe aware, it needs it's own HDMI input on your television. The better the hdmi connector you use, the better your picture will be. Also, in my opinion, it's better to use an ethernet cable than wireless, especially as our TV area is pretty far from the wireless router. All in all, I'm pretty happy with this, but I am a techno junkie.

I like how the appleTV just works.  The channels are abundant with a new PBS app and Smithsonian Channel app as well as the regular Netflix and Hulu apps and more.TIP:  If you click and hold on an app, it will select it, and not open it, and allow you to then relocate it with the arrow buttons.  This can help to stick apps you don't use at the bottom and bring ones you love up to the top for easy accessibility.
I like it very much, sadly after 4 months it stopped working, apparently I bought one of the bad ones, apple says they are gonna change it, I hope so!

I love how I can mirrow my iPad and iPhone and watch videos from my iPhone and even though Apple TV does not have Amazon Video I can still access the movie or TV show I want to watch from my Amazon Prime Instant Video app on my iPad or iPhone and use Air Play to watch it through my Apple TV.

Installation was very easy.  Plugged it into my tv hdmi port. Powered it up and up it came once I changed the input to the hdmi port.One thing I wish they would do for this is to allow a wireless keyboard interface or a smart phone keyboard interface.  It is slow to do a search and input the name/title/etc using the scroll and click method. I guess if you do it often enough it will get easier or faster.

I own both an Apple TV and a Roku 3.  I originally bought the Apple TV but quickly found myself wanting more channels.  As a primarily Apple user, I didn't want to replace the Apple TV because I love the airplay mirroring and streaming from my Mac or iOS devices.  The Apple TV is very fast and responsive, especially compared to the online apps in my Internet capable TV.  So far, I have not encountered any buffering or sync issues with the apple TV.  I originally had it connected with an ethernet cable but after purchasing the Roku, I now run it wireless in the family room.  I keep the Apple TV in the family room so other family members can mirror or stream from their iOS devices.As I mentioned, my only complaint with Apple TV is a lack of channels. The only premium channel available is HBO Go.  However, the only extra premium offered on Roku is Epix.  Also, some of the extra channels are pretty worthless, like SyFy.  Forget full episodes of current and former SyFy faves like Being Human, Helix or Battlestar Galactica.  The SyFy channel on Roku offers nothing more than snippets.  Dozens and dozens of minutes long snippets.  Uh, no thanks.  Apple TV does offer several news, weather, specialty and children's channels (like Disney).  There is no Amazon instant video as offered on Roku.  Movies and television shows that aren't available on any other channels must be purchased through iTunes.  The included remote is small and limited to basic playback functions or text entry using the directional arrows.  A remote app is available for free from iTunes that gives you more flexibility and is much more efficient for certain tasks, especially text entry.  The keyboard in the iOS remote app will make you never again want to use the directional arrows on the bundled remote.  All remotes work through the network, not bluetooth or infrared.  I can actually control the Apple TV in the family room from any other room.  Last week, I was able to display photos from my iPhone two rooms away.  In addition to the iPhone, the app works on iPods and iPads as well.So far, I've had my Apple TV since the end of November.  As of mid-January I have not experienced any major issues with A/V sync or buffering.  It worked flawlessly when I originally had it connected via an ethernet cable.  Once I switched to wifi, I still never encountered any sync issues, however, I'll occasionally get a very quick buffering.  It is infrequent and  doesn't last more than a second or two.  I actually get more buffering delays when watching streaming video wirelessly on much more powerful laptops.If you're trying to decide between Apple TV and Roku, I suggest Roku if you're really into watching online content and want the greatest variety of channels available.  Apple TV currently can't come close to the number of channels offered by Roku.  If you own a Mac or iOS devices and get your content primarily from iTunes or plan to do a lot of streaming /mirroring from your Apple device, Apple TV is a no-brainer.  I actually fall into both categories, so I own both.  With recent sale prices, they were still pretty affordable.

I purchased the Apple TV 3 days before the announcement that Apple had planned on silently releasing a new version of the Apple TV 3, currently being called 3,2 (designated model 1469). This information was discovered when Apple filed with the FCC regarding a newer device. The (4mm) smaller Apple TV will have the A5X chip and new low-power dual-band 40nm Broadcom BCM4334 chip that is present in new iDevices like the iPhone 5. This is not a major upgrade, and the average user will not notice a difference. However, I would rather wait a few more weeks and purchase the newest device available.

I purchased this product so that I could show content to my television without physically connecting them.  The streaming feature works only with designated content.  This content is not designated by me.  Instead on very limited items I can stream.  I wanted it to mirror my portable device.I was disappointed,David
I really like using the Apple TV to mirror my iPad screen on my HDTV. It was easy to setup and picture is perfect. Used cables before but this is 1000 times better.

It makes every TV a SMART TV and it is helping me to cut the cable cord.  I will not miss paying Comcast the cost of this unit every month.  It works so well I bought a second one for the bedroom. Now if it only worked with Prime.  Good thing my Panasonic TV does that already.

I tried this and the Roku. I found that the the Roku had WAY more channels (apps), but in the end, I opted for the Apple TV since I probably wouldn't even watch 1/16 of the media available on the Roku. The AirPlay functionality really sold me, as I am able to stream my Xfinity online media to my TV, as well as all the media that is not on the Apple TV yet. So who cares if I don't get the Korean News channel or the vintage horror movie channel...Between Hulu, Netflix, HBO, PBS, ABC, and the AirPlay option, I'm all set.The device itself is true Apple...High quality, great UI (Way better than Roku), easy to  use, and the remote is small, functional and works well from a distance. If you own a Mac, the remote also doubles as a remote for the computer as well.Great functionality with iTunes and Home sharing, as well. I am able to play my entire iTunes library through the Apple TV, which then goes through my sound bar.I love it! Keep those updates coming, Apple!

I use the Apple TV mainly for streaming Nexflix content to my television, and it works flawlessly for that purpose.  Setup was a breeze, and picture quality is also excellent, with hardly any need for buffering, but that can be due to cable usage in my neighborhood, or something else not necessarily the fault of the Apple TV.  Anyway, Apple needs to add more content, as I'm sure they eventually will, since Netflix (and Hulu Plus, if you so desire) are the only things worthwhile to me so far.  Yes, you can subscribe to sports programming but I'm not interested in those, and YouTube's quality varies immensely.  You can also play music from your computer (provided your computer is a recent model, and your OS is newer) to your stereo but I don't see the point of playing a low-fidelity medium on a high-fidelity system, and photos can also be streamed directly to your television.  All in all, a great product, albeit, limited in variety, so far.  However, if you subscribe to Netflix for its streaming then it is worth it for that alone.

I've been using my Apple TV for several months now and I feel that I have enough experience with this product to author an adequate and honest review.Pros:Awesome packaging! Your Apple TV box slides out of the packaging sleeve revealing your awesome little black hockey puck of a media streamer. Pulling the Apple TV out of its box reveals the remote made of sleek aluminum. The remote feels solid, incredibly simple and almost familiar. Underneath the remote resides the power cable, sans bulky power block as the Apple TV's power supply is actually inside the device itself, and owner's manual/warranty information.Simple setup! Plugging your Apple TV into power and then into your HDTV or Projector with an HDMI cable (Amazon Basics HDMI recommended, quality at a low price!). You are greeted with a dead-simple interface. Language? Wifi Network name and password? Apple ID and password? Done! From box to Netflix took about 2 minutes, tops.Blazing fast interface! I finally have a replacement for the sluggish "Smart" options on my Samsung LED TV. Getting to the middle of my Netflix queue on my Samsung took around 5 actual minutes before we were watching the movie/TV show. My Apple TV does the same job in less than 60 seconds.Features! Streaming options include iTunes Movies/Music/TV Shows (for purchase and for rental), Netflix, Hulu, MLB.TV, NBA LeaguePass, NHL On Demand, Wall Street Journal Online, Flickr, Vimeo, Youtube, AirPlay (next bullet point), and more being added in updates! Since I have owned mine, they have added several streaming options.AirPlay! Definitely something that sets the Apple TV apart from the competition. With a single tap on an Apple mobile device (iPod Touch, iPad or iPhone), you can wirelessly send media content to your TV! You even have the option to mirror your device's screen to the TV! Anything you do on your mobile device can be seen on the TV! Web browsing, Apps (HBO Go and other streaming services that aren't natively on the Apple TV), games, email, documents, anything! Awesome! This feature even extends to Macs.**NOTE** You can get AirPlay to function on non-Apple devices! Download AirParrot on Windows and DoubleTwist on Android to enable your ability to mirror your device to your Apple TV, wirelessly.Connectivity! Built-in wifi and bluetooth connectivity allowing you to connect a bluetooth keyboard for quick login and search entry. Recommend the Apple Wireless keyboard as it is very thin and light, great for couch use!Cons:Missing some streaming services like NFL and HBO Go, though these services are available if you have a device that can AirPlay this content from the web or an app.No native component connections, though this is a rare need in today's HDMI world.My Setup:Cox High Speed Internet 50MbpsMotorola Surfboard Extreme DOCSIS 3.0Apple Airport Extreme RouterSamsung UN40ES6500 40 inch LED 120hz 1080pApple TV (3rd generation, 1080p)Amazon Basics HDMI cableIn summary, this device is well worth the $99. It exceeds expectations in every regard, and allowed my wife and I to become "Cable-Cutters" and drop our cable TV service completely. We went from spending ~$150/month on television and blurays, HBO, Showtime, Starz, etc to spending ~$50 with Hulu Plus, Netflix and various purchases and rentals from the iTunes store. It paid for itself in the first month!
summary: Easy setup, awesome features, SPEED!! Cable-Cutters search no more!

reviewText: I was getting really sick of cable TV's exorbitant costs for channels that I will never watch in a million years.  So, I decided to cut the cable, so to speak, keep my internet connection, and opt for a pay-as-I-go media model.  Using Amazon Prime videos, primarily, and purchasing some shows that I want to watch, this has been great.  I'm saving big bucks and getting the programming I choose.It's a piece of cake to set up, and watching on my HDTV instead of my iMac is so much better.  I've read that if you already have Apple products in your home, this is the way to go, over Roku or other brands.  I don't know.  But, this works seamlessly.  The sound, the video, everything is better.  I highly recommend ditching cable TV.  It's old, gasping technology that will soon go by the wayside, as their greed will put them out of business.  Gotta love market forces.
I was skeptical at first, but with its Netflix capabilities and airplay the Apple TV has completely replaced my cable television!

I will always be loyal to my Apple products, and this one for sure has yet to let me down!It is fast, has heaps of cool features like Airplay, Remote App, and many other devices.Make sure you don't buy a blu-ray streaming player if all you use is youtube etc. The interface and remotes that come with other blu-ray streaming players don't function as well as this TV.Going to buy one for my wife for Christmas, oh and it looks great too so that's a bonus.

Literally plugged it in and set it up in less than 5 minutes - not kidding.  I'm not an apple kool-aid drinker so I didn't want to buy an Apple TV until I truly saw a benefit I couldn't live without.  Being able to stream my movie library with minimal effort was the kicker in the end.  The only problem I have is that my PC needs to be logged in for the Apple Home Sharing to work.  Obviously that's not an issue with the Apple TV box, it's a setting on my PC that needs to be changed.

Not sure how Apple has packed so much into such a small and affordable device. We've had 1st and 2nd generation AppleTV the 2nd gen has no internal hd and uses a ton less energy. I being the tech geek of the house had my doubts about being completely reliant on streaming which the 2nd and 3rd generation Atv's are. Over the past 2yrs Apple has made major improvements to the iOS and many services (streaming) make the device a great value. In the early days I did feel crippled by the lack of options but that is no longer an issue for example MLB network is now available if you have an MLB account. And then there are the obvious options like Netflix and streaming from your networked computers (that are running iTunes). My guess is things will only get better as Apple continues to add services through iCloud and hopefully streaming of live TV. Even without those the device is a bargain and completely idiot proof. :-)Note you can stream many cable channels via iPad - iPhone - iPod apps in HD. For example we often stream news channels like CNN to our Apple TV on our bedroom TV via my iPhone. However most apps require you have a TV provider... We have Dish sat service (only one receiver in our family room) having that account lets us use apps like CNN to watch their live streaming.Bottom line this is a great device and even greater if you have iDevices in your home. A great value.

Now that I've gotten it to work, I love it as much as I love all my iPhone.  The only thing was when I first got it, it would always freeze or stop working after about 10 minutes.  I drove myself INSANE trying to find a solution.  I was so upset about it!So the solution, if you're like me is that you have to go to your router in any internet broswer by typing in the ip address, log in, and add in the atv's ip address as always allowed.  I don't trully understand why this is, but the explanation is something about devices are constantly "reconnecting" to the router, and this is what disrupts the atv's performance and ruins everything until fixed.  They say modern routers don't do this, but mine is only a few months old, so I think it's a problem with atv that it doesn't work out of the box or at least make it easier to find this solution which it took me HOURS to find.  I hope if you have this problem you find this review sooner.
summary: I love it, but I had problems with it freezing... (solved)

reviewText: Out of the box, aTV "found" my iPod 4th gen.  I was able to display pics off of the iPod... that was it.  No vids, no games (mirroring), nope - nothing else.  Thought about returning it then, but decided to wait to see how well it works with a new MBP.MBP (2.6GHz i7 16GB, dual 7.2k rpm hd): what a waste of my time.  I upgraded to ML just for aTV...  Yes, mirroring worked, but not like for viewing movies at full resolution/24fps.  My MBP was 12' from the router, the aTV located 8' from the router.  (btw, a $130 Linksys/Cisco N router).  As for "mirroring", well, slow at best - most of the time there was a 12 sec delay... on anything.  So frustrating.  I "reverted" back to Lion where Airplay worked for pics...  oh but not so well for vids/movies.iPad 2nd/iPad mini- oh forget it.  Decided to return the aTV to Amazon.Pros:  Can display pics on the iPod/iPad very well on your home lcd.  This has great potential for photo studio purposes if one uses wireless units in their dSLRs.  aTV has really nice screen saver and the menu driven interface is as one would expect from Apple products.  Intuitive, easy to use, high quality.  Wireless configuration was such a breeze!  The packaging for this is second to none.  The included remote works with other Mac/Apple products - very nice.Cons: Video files cannot be some of the more popular file formats.  Basically, they all need to be in Apple's iTunes compatible formats.  Price is a bit high, but consistent o all Apple's products...  ( this would have been my 6/7th Apple product).The concept of being able to display my MBP screen onto a selectable (if you have more than one aTV in your location) LCD in my home/office wirelessly is really cool.  Maybe in the next release this will work.  BTW, for AirPlay works on Lion - you do not have to upgrade to ML.
summary: So disappointing, I wish aTV was great/even good...

reviewText: Pros: AirPlay mirroring, Super Compact, Easy Set Up, Great User Interface, 1080Cons:  Limited Apps, AirPlay mirroring blocked by Comcast/HBO using portable devices (iPad, iPhone), Doesn't work with other devices, no control of AirPlay when mirroring from iMac in other room.My favorite feature with Apple TV is the AirPlay mirroring.  When I am visiting friends without cable, Netflix or Hulu, or on the road traveling, I can easily get access to these shows or live streaming if I bring my ATV along with my iPad and connect to an HDMI device.But, outside of ATV's AirPlay mirroring, I am left wondering what else can I do?Apps on ATV are very limiting.  If you are buying this for the current app line up and not Airplay Mirroring, I suggest buying a Wireless Sony Blue Ray DVD player.  Head to head, the DVD player has far more usable apps than Apple does, it plays DVDs, Blue Rays, and even does 3D DVDs... and cost $130 vs $95.  Well worth the extra $35... but it doesn't do AirPlay mirroring.When using AirPlay mirroring, I am limited to controlling streaming from the device which is being mirrored.  With the iPad this isn't a problem... but if I am using the iMac which is located on the other end of the house, this isn't fun, but is good exercise.  I can't even pause a movie.  If your question is why don't you just mirror it from your iPad, well the answer is that not everything can be mirrored from portable devices.  Comcast & HBO have blocked the ability to mirror from your iPad/iPhone, but not the case from my iMac.  It would be nice if the ATV gave some control to pause the iMac in the other room.UPDATE to Mirroring:  HBO recently updated their app and I can now mirror HBO Go on my Apple TV from my iPad.  Additionally, I have been able to use the remote to pause, rewind and fast forward... or simply use my iPad to control everything.  This is a much better improvement and makes me raise my star review to 4 stars.After getting the ATV, I shelled out $25 for a yearly subscription to iTune's Match.  That was 3 weeks ago and 90% of my music has been uploaded.  The first 80% took a few hours, the remaining 20% is taking forever because the music wasn't matched from iTunes catalog.  I understand some of my music isn't on iTunes, but there seems to be some that is on iTunes that isn't getting matched from the iTunes library.  Match allows me to AirPlay my music from the Cloud in another room with ATV without connecting to my computer.  This is especially useful when on the road.Not all Netflix & Hulu apps are the same and ATV wins easily for their interface.  I have these services built in on my Vizio Via TV in our bedroom and the Sony Blue Ray in our living room.  Apple TV wins easily in user interface.  The Sony comes last in quality.  It is a bit wonky, the layout is weird, and reading titles is nearly impossible.  The Vizio is a bit better, but is also limiting.  The Apple TV is clear, easy to navigate and even gives you extra search features in Netflix.  For example, on some movies you can go to the cast list and click on each cast member to find other movies they appear in. The layout is well thought out and easy to navigate. Great!I have high hopes for ATV in the future.  Coming from Apple, I expected more Apps and they should be delivering on this ASAP.  Additionally, giving the user two way control using AirPlay mirroring is much needed.  I should be able to pause my iMac in another room from my ATV.  Finally, ATV will reign supreme if the user can also mirror and control a remote computer from another room on a television using a keyboard/mouse or trackpad... in essence, giving the user the feeling of having a 2nd computer in another room.This is what I expect from Apple and until then I really can't give it a better rating.
summary: When Apple adds more apps, I will reconsider a higher rating

reviewText: Pros: The best in home networking with other iOS devices. Connects flawlessly and integrates smoothly.Cons: Besides Netflix and Hulu, there really isn't much this thing offers in the video department. And you're insane if you think I'm gonna rent/buy from the Apple store with their prices. Things like Crackle, Xfinity, HBO/Cinemax Go aren't available so there really isn't much content.Fortunately I still have an Xbox 360.
summary: Great for iOS homes but lacking in video sources

reviewText: that's all I have to say. It's an Apple product. Compatibility with other apple products is as easy as it comes.  it works flawlessly!
The AppleTV always impresses me. It's amazing how you can watch something on your computer A button and then watch it on the television the children love it.
summary: This might be the 21TH century's greatest invention,really fun, and incredibly easy to use from great grandpa to the baby's use.

reviewText: The Apple TV is the best companion device for your iOS devices and iTunes. Even if the AirPlay Mirroring is the only feature you ever use, it would have been well worth it.I have completely replace my cable provider with Netflix, Hulu Plus, and iTunes. This is one of the best purchases I have ever made, and the 1080p video quality is just awesome.To anyone who is already invested in the iTunes ecosystem, I would highly recommend getting an Apple TV to compliment your visual experience. You won't regret it.

The Apple TV MD199LL/A has two basic functions. It's an audio/video streaming device like the Roku and it's a wireless connection device between your iPad and your television - that's the "Airplay" feature.  My family has both the most recent Roku and the Apple TV. The Roku and the Apple TV have more similarities than differences. Both are compact, easy to set up, compact, have a simple menu navigation system and provide excellent streaming. Not surprisingly, the Apple TV features iTunes store rentals and purchase of music and movies and Apple Radio. The Roku doesn't have Apple Store but basically has all the competitors, Vudu, Amazon, etc.  As a device for streaming movies, I'd give the nod to the Roku.  The ace up Apple's sleeve though is the iPad connectivity. With Airplay turned on I can play whatever is on my iPad (iPad 3 in my case) on my television (projector in my case) through the Apple TV. This makes the Apple TV the perfect accessory for a home theater system. Instead of playing my ipad through it's on board speaker or headphones, I can play it through the home theater system speakers while I carry it rather than have it tied to the charging stand.  I stream a lot of Pandora, Sirius/XM and Youtube music videos. Lately I've been getting into Apple Radio also.  The audio and video quality of Airplay streamed content is great. There is some lag (latency) that makes airplay connections unsuitable for most games.  By the way, I tried playing software instruments on the iPad through using the Airplay audio. As I expected, there was too much latency, at least a full second between when I hit the notes and when the sound arrived. I didn't notice the same latency playing movies. The iPad must compensate on streamed video feeds.  I think it would be great if Apple came out with an Audio-only over airplay mode which would allow a huge reduction in latency.  We'll see if it happens.  I'm giving the Apple TV five stars, because for under $100.00, it's a very useful little box. If you have an iPad and a home theater receiver, the Apple TV will increase your enjoyment of both.
summary: Great iPad Companion - with Roku 3 comparison Plus can you play iPad instruments over Airplay?

reviewText: The hardware is elegant and it was easy to setup. The initial update took some time but I was streaming from my iTunes library and Hulu in no time. Picture quality is great. The remote is simplistic and the menus are easy to navigate.Update: I have been using my iPhone with the Apple tv's airplay ability to stream video and music from my phone and it works great.

The only reason I bought this over a Roku was it's ability to AirPlay my iPad. It's still a great piece of hardware, but if you want more options for content and don't have an iOS device to stream to it, then get a Roku.
summary: Works well, but needs more apps.

reviewText: There are so many great features, I'll try to highlight the ones that are most important:When plugged into the HDMI port of your television, you will have to switch the input to HDMI. Once that is done the startup screen will show up. It will want to link to your home wi-fi network so choose that network and use the enclosed Apple TV Remote to enter the password for the network (if you have a password on your network-if you don't, you REALLY should).APPLE MAGIC: Once you have linked the Apple TV to your Wi-Fi network, and if you have a newer version of your iPhone or iPad, make sure that this device (iPad or iPhone) has Bluetooth enabled (check Settings)  and is on the same network as your Apple TV. Then tap (yes, physically tap) the iPhone or iPad on the Apple TV (just a tap, you're not trying to break it) and the iPhone or iPad will link to the Apple TV which will make setup very very easy because you will be able to use the keyboard on your iDevice rather than the Apple TV Remote. BE ADVISED: this doesn't always work so if it doesn't you will have to complete the setup using the Apple TV Remote. If you have an under 25 child in the house who texts regularly, let them use the Apple TV remote to finish the rest of setup; it's so much easier for them!).Once you have the setup completed, use the Apple TV Remote to select options for you.EASIER: If you have a later iPhone or iPad, go to the App Store and download Remote (it's free). This will allow you to link with your Apple TV and not use the Apple TV Remote, which is a good thing.What fun things can it do?If you have a later model iPhone or iPad, you can project the image on your device directly on your television.If you have iOS 6; Click your home button twice and then slide the apps button to the right until you see a small square with a filled triangle on the bottom half. This is the AirPlay button. Tap it and choose the Apple TV as the source. Then slide the "Mirroring" slider to the on position. Within a few seconds your device's screen will show up on your television screen.If you have iOS 7: Slide the controls panel up from the bottom of your home screen. The AirPlay button is labeled. Tap it and choose the Apple TV as the source. Then slide the "Mirroring" slider to the on position. Within a few seconds your device's screen will show up on your television screen.You can watch Netflix, YouTube, Sports, you can stream any media that you have purchased from Apple including Music, TV, Movies, etc.You will find that the Apple TV is a welcome addition to your technology. Even if it's the only Apple device you have.
summary: A major addition to your "wired" home.

reviewText: The unit worked flawlessly right of the box. Easy to hook-up and use. Very versatile unit. Offers a variety movie programming sources. Replaced the Logic Revue, which never worked correctly.

This is a great product by apple, and I love it.Some things to consider:APPLE TV DOES NOT SUPPORT OLDER TVS. ONLY OUTPUTS THROUGH HDMI.To enjoy it to its max, you probably want an iTunes account, Netflix account, etc.What comes with the Apple TV is what you get. No app store like Roku.For me, with a Netflix account, YouTube account(not required), and iTunes account, and iPod Touch, it's very worth what I paid for.

This is an awesome piece if you have apple products. I purchased this so my daughter could play her learning games on our ipad through our TV. It works wonders when they are trying to learn there ABC's etc. I also use this for netflix and hulu even though i have a smart tv the apple apps seem to work better and stream at a better quality. I would highly recommend this to anyone with kids or those who have apple products.

This is just awesome! We have Roku and this is the perfect addition for more TV options. This also offers a lot of other options besides just watching movies. You can turn your TV into a huge digital photo slide show, or listen to yout iTunes library. A perfect addition to any entertainment center.

This is just what I needed. I had been using a mini-port to HDMI cable to mirror my Mac. Worked great for several months. When I downloaded an HD trailer and tried to play it, the connection flickered out. I tried two different cables to no avail. the connection would come and go (mostly go). I had never been interested in an ATV, but research indicated that it might be a good way to mirror the Mac. Ordered it, set it up, bang: off to the races (I have a late 2011 MBP, so air-play works fine). It is what it is. I don't do a lot of streaming, so I'm not missing the access to various venues mentioned by others. I like the interface with iTunes. The initial reason for my interest in connecting the computer to my home theater system (such as it is) was the ability to drive high impedance headphones. I also enjoy the interface with YouTube. Those rotating still frames are pretty cool. My often lame DSL is slow to load content (and sometimes just fails) but that's not the fault of the ATV. As for mirroring, my only disappointment is the slight lag time. I work in graphics programs via a Wacom tablet and this slight lag is not a good thing (but I don't mind working directly on the Mac these projects). If my local Apple store wasn't constantly crowded, I would have spent some time at the genius bar to see what's up with the lightening port (Apple Care wasn't able to get it figured out, and I found many blog posts about the problem). Bottom line: For basic use, this is a solid product. I don't regret buying it. Oh, BTW, the free remote  app works great with my iPod 5G. That's a definite plus.

This is such an easy to use and necessary accessory to anyone that has a Macbook Pro, IPad or even Iphone.  The picture looks fantastic!  And it takes up very little space and uses almost no electricity.  Our Blu-Ray Player has not been turned on since we hooked up Apple Tv.  A couple of things to note before buying this product:1.  You must update your Macbook Pro Operating System to Mountain Lion to use it with Apple TV.  Mirroring will not work otherwise.  There is a cost of $20 to do this update and it will change your computer in many ways (including slowing it down and taking longer to boot up).  However, after using cords to connect my computer to my tv, I will take the bad qualities of Mountain Lion anytime.  The sound comes through crystal clear, picture is great.2.  Mirroring does not look very good coming from IPhone or IPad 2.But there are so many great things about this.  We are purchasing a surround sound system since it picks up the shared music on my itunes.Netflix looks great and HD comes through wonderfully.  I also love the "Remote" app on my iphone, which allows me to control the apple tv from my phone.  No need for a remote!!!! My wife and I can both have our own remotes and control the music, shows and pictures at the drop of a hat.With technology, comes convenience and this product made my life a lot easier.Thank you Apple

This little box has gotten me away from my computer, and watching Hulu and Netflex on my television. The remote is the neatest gadget. All of my other remotes have many buttons. The Apple TV's remote has three, and it is amazing what those three buttons allows you to control.

This product is amazing! you can rent movies, listen to music, watch photos and movies from your iPhone, iPad, Mac, and PC directly in your TV! I'm very happy with this Apple TV. You can even mirror your Mac computer in the TV without any cables

Updated review:After Amazon reviewer sandvfan pointed out that the "channels" that I said Apple TV lacked were actually hidden under Podcast, I went to an Apple Store to check out this feature. And indeed, there is a huge treasure chest of video and audio Podcasts - much more comprehensive that what Roku has, and the menu system and search feature are excellent.Yesterday, I returned the Roku 2 XS that I bought at Costco, and bought myself an Apple TV. I can overlook Apple TV's lack of Amazon Instant Video because my Blu-ray player has that feature.Old review:I tried both the latest Apple TV (third generation) and Roku 2 XS before deciding on the Roku.In short, the only advantage of Apple TV is its tight integration with iTunes. I also like its remote controller better.But if you are into high quality, free channels, the Apple TV pales by comparison. Even the least costly Roku LT ($50) supports 400+ channels. The channels that I use most are Amazon Instant Video (Amazon Prime members can watch free movies), Crackle (free movies), Cnet, Revision3, Tested, TED, and a number of news channels.Apple TV does NOT support Amazon Instant Video. It is a closed system, compared to Roku's vendor-neutral design. Even though I have many Apple products, I had to choose the more versatile Roku over the rather limited Apple.You can try out Apple TV at a Apple Store, and you can buy a Roku 2 XS at Costco which you can return within 90 days if you are not satisfied. The Roku at Costco is a special bundle: Roku 2 XS, HDMI cable, and 2 months of Hulu+ free - all for $90. The only thing I don't like about the Roku is its paltry 90-day warranty. Reviews on the Amazon site do not seem to indicate unreliable hardware, so I am not too concerned about this aspect. You can use the Chase Amazon credit card to buy this and get a doubling of the warranty to 180 days.
summary: Apple TV Is Better! (Old Title: The Roku2 XS Is A Much More Versatile Product)

reviewText: Using two Apple TVs and an Airport Express, I have created 3 zones with connected speakers in my home. This is wonderful for playing music from iTunes or my families iOS devices. From any audio application on iPhones or iPads it is easy to send the audio to the Apple TV and even mirror the video to the Apple TV.It's not perfect. We also have a Roku device to connect with nearly all other streaming multimedia applications that we use such as Pandora, Amazon Instant, HBO Go, etc. Apple TV however makes easy browsing of Internet video services.Setup is quick and painless, and you can easily access your Apple music and video library.
summary: 3G Apple TV w/ AirPlay Makes Brilliant Home Entertainment System

reviewText: Very happy with this device. Keeps getting better with more apps, and upgrades in Apple services. I am getting one for every TV in our house. Great for Netflix and HULU, but Airplay is the real winner.
summary: Awesome for every TV in house.

reviewText: Very limited apps for this. We have a Roku and were given this as a present. Honestly, I would have taken it back to the store and bought another Roku if that was an option.It works well for Netflix and I assume pay per view movies, but doesn't offer a service for Amazon prime or various other channels. Seems to be severely limited in its capabilities, yet more expensive. Maybe if I had more Apple products, this device would better suit my needs.

was torn between 4 and 5 stars because:Easily 5 stars in terms of how much I enjoy owning/using, but4 stars because there are things I'd like to change without having to jailbreak.PROS:A) Instantaneous streaming (assuming you have a fast network)from:a) your computer*b) media purchased or rented from iTunes Store.c) Music in iMatch (puts music from non-iTunes store music in the cloud) but costs $25d) photos from iPhoto (MacOnly) or PhotoStreamBy far the fastest most capable wireless or LAN based system I've tried for streaming from your computer  -- Love it or hate it: what makes the system work so well is that iTunes does all the heavy lifting rather than the device, (or incomprehensibly slow Windows Media Player - perhaps this will improve with new xBox). So your passion for this device assumes you like/love and/or can at least tolerate iTunes*.A1) Can play visitors music and videos: I assume this only true if they're running iOS devices. Keep forgetting to try with Android bearing guests, but sincerely doubt it would work without special software.B)Truly brain-dead set up (if you bother reading 3 pages of included manual) download it if you lost it.C)Free stuff: Watch/listen to Podcasts, play YouTube, Vimeo, Movie Trailers, Flickr, digital Radio Stations etc. As well as standard paid services (Netflix, Hulu Plus, MLB,WSJ, NFL etc)*Frankly if you're going to purchase an ATV its worth your while to learn how to really take advantage of iTunes capabilities like using smart playlists.CONS:a) They've made your computers media a couple more clicks away than ATV 1 (you used to be able to access from top level (main screen). You have to choose "Computers" first..b) Requires Home Sharing (This is a free software service built into iTunes - which determines who can play and or copy your purchased media). While I've never had any problem (even with my PC) some folks (nearly all are PC users) do. It seems this is mostly do to firewall/router settings and/or 3rd party antivirus software. Nonetheless, if you run into an issue, you need to be willing to read thru Apple's KBs on the topic,  (or call Apple and have them walk your thru it if your still under warranty.)c) No way to backdate software without jailbreaking, AND, as of Apple TV Gen 2, you can't disable updates completely (you're asked before updating, but it gets to be a pain constantly clicking "Don't Update".)-- A WASH: Pro or Con depending on your needs so YMMV---the Remote: Lots of folks like how simple and small this is. Personally I'd rather have a remote that's less likely to land in the wash. There are actually quite a lot of "hidden" commands in the device - like holding down select while playing a video to select chapter, I believe most/all? of these documented online, but personally I'd prefer separate NAMED buttons.No Amazon Video Player: If you don't have another device which has the software, and you really prefer using amazon media only, you might prefer a different device. For me this is no biggy, since I play my amazon music thru the ATV, and watch the "free" Amazon Prime Instant videos (well sorta free, since I pay an annual fee to amazon for the privilege) thru my Blu-Ray player, or TV.

We got rid of cable because of this fantastic little device. Between various download services and the relatively easy time we had finding a program to convert files to Apple format, we can stream almost anything to our tv except for live material. The integrated services work really easily and the quality is flawless without buffering. Wifi connection was a simple password and apple found our non-apple based network without a blip. My only complaint is that the quite stylish remote, while solid, is not ergonomically easy to use if you have big fingers. It's hard telling where the guide "bumps" on the circle are compared to the button part in the center.
Work great - new to the techie world and this allow me to watch movies from my IPAD on my TV -- Good times

Works great. I wish it had more apps for watching other online content.
