Not necessarily games and such, but apps that would allow access to video content from popular websites something like the Roku or XBMC plugins. I actually was about to buy the Roku but then found out that it's Netflix app does not work here in South America, so I went with the Apple TV although I do not own any other Apple devices... and I have to say that it works very well within it's limitations.
summary: Looking for a small device to use as a Netflix box...

reviewText: **17Sept 2013 edit**. I just got an update for Amazon Instant Video this morning, and itis now available over AirPlay to Apple TV!  Hurrah!I opted for the Apple TV over Roku products because I'm an Apple user (I've got an Ipad2 and an Iphone 4s, both of which are Airplay compatible).  I'm also an Amazon Prime member who watches a lot of television shows through the Ipad app.  One reason I chose the Apple TV was because of Airplay with my Ipad, I could watch Amazon Prime videos (one feature of the Roku that I really liked.)  Well, it arrived last night, and the Amazon Prime app is not available to stream over Airplay.Well played, Amazon.  Well played.That being said, the Airplay function is worth it.  I used velcro to attach the small design to the back of my small television and the signal from the remote bounces off the wall behind it to the box, eliminating line of sight necessity for the remote.The remote app on Ipad/Iphone is seriously easy to use and cool.  I also tried out a flight simulater game that uses the Ipad as a control panel and the television as game screen (I usually don't play these types of games.  I just really wanted to try out this feature.)  It was fun!
summary: With one exception, I love it.

reviewText: Apple is obsessed with miniaturization, but what they need to learn is that if the device is not made to be carried around with you, miniaturization is not always a positive. For example, the Apple TV remote is about the size of a stick of chewing gum, and only has 7 buttons. Sure, why would we need a variety of buttons when we can just hit these 7 buttons 16 zillion times every time we need to navigate through the user interface? I'm sure Apple sycophants are falling all over themselves saying how wonderfully intuitive the remote is, but Apple could come out with a device that stabs these people in the eye every 15 seconds, and they would be blogging about how wonderful and user friendly it is within minutes.Furthermore, I cannot watch Amazon Prime instant videos on it. Apple is always in a dispute with someone, so I am sure this is not a technical issue, but another Apple money grab. These people sue other companies for having rounded corners for crying out loud. EVERY OTHER STREAMING DEVICE WORKS WITH AMAZON PRIME!!! How can anyone say this device is superior when it is the only one that cannot do this.
As always, Apple products deliver, works effortlessly. Would recommend to everyone, no skill level required to set up, just plug it in
Best little investment for crap TV programing that exists today!  Pick your own genre and never watch a hemmeorid commercial again!
summary: Apple TV is a hit!  Great altenative to Garbage on the air waves today!

reviewText: For anyone who relies on closed captioning to enjoy video, this little purchase is a major breakthrough.  Streaming Netflix was previously of no value to me, except on my little iPad screen.  Now the great world of Netflix content is available to me with captions on my television.  I don't care about anything else that Apple TV can do ( mirroring is cool).  For me, it's all about the closed captions.

Great product especially if you are apple lover and owner such as me. This will work great with apple products to easy stream thing to your tv fast.2 things that bug me at the moment but could be fixed.1. My apple tv makes a harsh, weird, and extremely annoying sound about every hour it still plays whatever is playing but with a incredible amount of distortion I cant seem to find whats wrong it does it on every app and evern when im streaming this makes me think its the box itself.2. Apple tv needs a app store just like the iphone app store the ipad app store and the mac app store come on apple why not?
summary: 2 main reasons why it doesnt get a 5 star.

reviewText: I can definitely be labeled as an Apple junkie and generally have high regard for most of their products.  Sadly, the Apple TV doesn't reach the same high level of performance as the iPhone and iPad products.  After about three months, I converted from the Apple TV to a Roku 3 and have been very happy with the change.  The Roku simply gives you more channels, has a better interface, is faster, is simply easier to use.  I did enjoy being able to project my iPad or iPhone onto a TV screen using Airplay and Apple TV, but unfortunately, the only way that functionality works is when you are on your home network.  You cannot travel with an Apple TV and expect to use it in a hotel.  You can use your phone as a personal hotspot to establish a network and gain all of the Apple TV capabilities, but you will burn through your data plan very quickly.  If you try to establish your own network using a mobile router then you will quickly find that almost none of your Apple content is authorized to play.  All in all, this was biggest disappointment I have experienced with an Apple product.  Go with a Roku, you'll be much happier.
summary: Just Too Limited to be Worth the Money

reviewText: I don't watch "regular" TV at all and haven't for many years so I decided to ditch the cable service and go with 2nd generation ATV back in 2010. For me and the family it was mainly about watching movies and some educational documentaries a few times per week through iTunes and Netflix. Being that we're also a Mac and iOS family with numerous Macs and iOS devices around the house, the ATV became more useful than just streaming movies and shows to the HDTV set. Now with iCloud it's the wireless router that brings all of the content available through the Mac and iOS ecosystem to the TV screen and the home theater audio system. Gone are the big unsightly black boxes and cables that cluttered the TV cabinet along with the racks of CDs and DVDs. With all the content on iTunes Match and the iOS devices, it's just a matter of using the remote or the iDevices themselves to control what you watch and listen to through the ATV.The value of the ATV is that much greater if you have already invested in the Apple ecosystem - Macs, iPhones, iPads, iPod touch, iTunes content, etc. The ATV on its own, I gather, isn't all that great compared to what's already out there. For TV freaks who put in 4~5 hours of TV time per day, I'd imagine there are more thorough and feature-rich devices out there. But as an extension device of all things Apple to the TV screen, this little unit works charmingly well and provides more than enough content for the casual TV watcher and movie fan. I'd only really recommend this unit to iOS device owners and there are plenty of them out there.Apple still has ways to go to make the TV an integral part of its growing ecosystem. One can tell that Apple is getting more and more serious about this business and that it isn't just a "hobby" anymore. These little ATV boxes seem more like a real-world R&D; testing for Apple's rumored HDTV set that could arrive near the end of this year or sometime in 2013. The key will be content and Apple still has a lot of work to do on that front. For me, live sports would be the only thing I'd consider to be essential to make it perfect but I know most other people have other wants and needs when it comes to what they want to watch. In the meantime, this new ATV would be a great addition to iPhone/iPad owners and a reasonable add-on for others who want to stream movies and archived TV shows every now and then.
summary: Perfect Way To Make the TV Part of the Apple Ecosystem

reviewText: If you own Apple products, you need to get this. It has the simplicity, reliability and clean interface of a typical Apple product. I wish I would have gotten this years ago. I read all the reviews particularly the ones comparing them to Roku III. but in retrospect, it was a wasted effort. Apple users prefer intuitive simple to use features with a clean interface. That's what this provides. I'm not a gamer. I'm not someone who can't afford to pay for items and needs to jail break an item to get free apps. I'm too busy to watch or need 1000 apps/stations/channels whatever you want to call it.  Yeah, the Apple TV doesn't have as many apps as the Roku but it has the only apps that you will really need. What you want is what I wanted. You want a device that won't lose connection. You want something that is easy to use. You want a clean interface. You want to be able to import your iTunes so you can play music over your television for when you have guests over or just provide a nice ambience in the home. You want to be able to view your photos and videos on your television.  This product does not deserve less than 5 stars.
summary: If you're an Apple person, get this

reviewText: If you're tied to your iTunes account or want to use Screen Mirroring from your iPad then this is the best box for you.  However, if you just want a smart media streamer you'd do better with an Android Mini PC.  Available on Amazon for as little as $30.

I have a Roku, and only chose it over Apple TV because it didn't offer hulu+, or mirroring from a computer. But just last week they added hulu, and they launched Mountain Lion that allowed for mirroring from my Mac, all while my Roku became incredibly slow to take any commands from the remote, and would sometimes just freak out. I got the Apple TV and so far it's been fantastic. It hasn't slowed down like the Roku did, yet, and it's great to be able to watch things like the Olympics on my TV through my computer that's streaming it from the NBC website. Plus, it's just one more thing to harmoniously sync with iCloud, and that always feel good. I'm really happy with the switch.

I have bought three AppleTVs in the past year for myself and family. If you have any Apple product that supports AirPlay, this is a must-have companion.We had a party recently, and everyone loved pulling out their iPhones and playing their favorite songs or home videos through our home theater system. It was a great experience.The PhotoStream screensaver makes your TV into a giant digital picture frame. Any picture I've taken with my iPhone, or edited with my MacBook shows up automatically.Airplay Mirroring lets you show your entire iPhone, iPad, or new MacBook screen to your TV screen. You can scroll through photos, watch videos, or anything really, all over wireless, all through your home theater system. This is the future.With Netflix and now HuluPlus, cutting cable TV is much easier. We eliminated our cable box recently and barely miss it.The AppleTV is simply a great device that gets more features every update. The Apple ecosystem is a great place to be.
summary: Must have companion for any Apple product

reviewText: I heard Apple TV when it was first appeared with mixed responses from users several years ago. But this time I decided to order it because of its new Airplay function. It arrived safely and on time.  It worked so beautifully that now it becomes the only channel we watch TV. Thanks!

I know a lot of folks who praise AppleTV and when my Panasonic streaming device crapped out...I thought I'd give it a try.  Yes, I should have looked over the product specs in more detail but there were two reasons I was forced to return it.  One, it doesn't support Amazon Prime.  Two, you have to use the TV in order to stream music.  I ended up getting a Roku and an Airport for the music.  Apple needs to get this figured out.

I love Apple products, but this one needs work.  It is amazing to use Airplay to be able to mirror my screen on my TV and stream music through the big stereo in my room.  But, this device has some serious technical problems.  It regularly disconnects from the wireless network for no apparent reason.  It also constantly disconnects airplay from my computer and makes me turn airplay on and off through the menu of the AppleTV to get it to work again.  I have been stuck in bed after surgery twice in the last four months.  Each time, I used the Apple TV very regularly to stream music or watch movies.  I would estimate I had a problem about five times a day that required power cycling the Apple TV or turning settings on and off in menus because they randomly stopped working.  This product has a lot of potential if they can get it to be stable.
I love having both! They both have it's pros and cons. There are no which one is better, they both make me happy!
summary: I love my Apple TV and my Roku 3!

reviewText: In the box you get the Apple TV, which is a small black box measuring only 23mm x 98mm x 98mm that weighs just 0.27kg, a nice-looking aluminum remote with very few buttons, some setup instructions and a power lead. The Apple TV has exactly the same ports and connectors on the back as before. There's an ethernet port, an Optical Audio port and a HDMI port for connection to your TV. You'll also notice a Micro-USB port, but this has no use for the home user - it's just for Apple's Geniuses to use when diagnosing problems. The Apple TV processor has been upgraded to the A5 chip to cope with 1080p HD movie playback. iFixit has done a teardown on the Apple TV and found that the Broadcom 4330 Wi-Fi chip inside also supports Bluetooth 4.0+HS, although it currently makes no use of this technology - it's possible that the functionality could be added in a future update. The current Apple Remote uses Infrared, this requires line of site to your Apple TV, which can be a pain - a Bluetooth remote would be far superior.Connection to your TV is via a HDMI cable, but be aware that there isn't one in the box, so you have to purchase that separately.The first surprise with the new Apple TV compared to the previous generation is that once you connect it up to your TV is that it talks to you! A voice asks you if you'd like to enable the Voice Over feature by clicking a button on the remote three times.Voice Over reads out what the menu option you've currently got selected is, so it will be a very useful feature for visually impaired users who need extra help navigating the menu systems.Proceeding on, you set up the usual things like language then select a WiFi network - if you've never done this before then it will be your first encounter with the Apple TV's tedious way of entering text and numbers - you have an alphabetically ordered block of letters that you have to have to slowly manoeuvre around using the remote's click wheel. t's frustrating to use because the layout is so unfamiliar - having the letters arranged like a computer keyboard would have been more intuitive.Going through the process of painfully entering your WiFi password one character at a time using this input method only to realise you got one of the characters wrong and have to do it all over again is heartbreaking, especially when at this stage you just want to get on with enjoying all the great content your Apple TV promises. It's a shame Apple still use this input method because everything else about the Apple TV is so easy to use it stands in sharp contrast to other media streamers.
I purchased this for my mother to watch shows on the TV since it has a bigger screen. She loves it and would never go back to watching it via the computer or smartphone.
summary: Perfect for people with bad vision.

reviewText: it may be more limited in some aspects, but as far as build quality and reliability there isn't anything else close.  if you already own apple products, this is a no-brainer.  plus, apple is set to add much more content in the near future (others are trying, but apple has the $ to pull it off).chromecast is a joke, even at $35, or whatever their latest "promo" is (google netflix promo, what a scam).  just a failed google tv stripped down.  don't believe me, google it.

It's tiny. It's energy efficient. It's a  total breeze to integrate into an existing HDMI based home theater system. Netflix picture quality very good on a fast broadband connection. I'm using a 12mb VDSL link. Netflix supports Dolby D.  I'm very pleased.  Oh, did I mention that if you have a recent iPHone you can Airplay videos and pictures to your TV!Excellent product.  If you are an Apple product user,  i.e. iPhone, Macbook,  iPad, iTunes this is an inexpensive and essential addition to your multimedia system.Now if it would just support Amazon Prime video :)
I wish every techie item was this easy to set-up and get working!  Works well with my 60 inch Sony.  I can't believe the picture quality in HD from Netfix over the WiFi!  Wow.

My excellent Roku 1 died last month after 6 years of wonderful service. I bought a Roku 3 last year for my second TV and it works incredibly well!! I was torn between replacing my dead Roku with another Roku 3 (which I know works extremely well) or getting the Apple TV so I can leverage my iTunes collection, and other Apple devices that I've accumulated over the last couple of years. Pros of Roku 3 and Apple TV:Roku 3 ProsExtremely fast user interfaceHeadphone jack on the remoteRemote easier to useApple TV ProsAccess to iTunes digital library - music, movies and TV shows (items purchased on iTunes)Access to "Home Sharing" on iTunes - music and photos (not purchased on iTunes)Access to iMovies program from laptopAirPlay feature for iOS devicesThe only thing missing from Apple is Amazon Prime. But I understand that you can use the iPad Prime App with AirPlay. I don't use Amazon Prime that much, so its not that big of a deal to me. If you don't have other Apple products, I would recommend getting the Roku 3. If you do have an iTunes library with Digital copies of movies, I would recommend getting this unit.

Ok, I bought this product thinking I can share my music and video from my iPhone and iPad using my home entertainment center and TV and it does work great and everyone is happy. Now, another feature of this product is to be able stream and/or download movies to watch. Well, streaming works fairly good depending on the sites you go to such as Netflix BUT if you go to the Apple site and try to download a movie to watch, forget it, you might as well get in your car, drive to the video store, rent a movie, go have dinner with family, stop for gas and come home and then "maybe" the download is complete. Bottom line, good for music sharing and streaming video, not so good for downloading.

Picked up the AppleTV in an attempt to cut the cord with cable.  We are a few weeks into the experiment and are not looking back!Setup: Pretty much just plug it in and set up your wifiInterface: Simple, intuitive and very smooth.iTunes Content: Tons of iTunes content.  Great selection of movies, but I wish the prices were better.  I see no reason to purchase TV shows, but others might.  Got me back into podcasts, there is an amazing about of content.3rd Party Content: My son lives in Netflix, he never used it on the Wii but now accessing content is much easier.  Vimeo has some great content, much more polished then YouTube.  MLB.TV is great, but I with they didn't follow the blackout rules.Remote: Remote is simple, but the remote app (iPhone/iPad) makes it much easier to use.AirPlay: This is the killer feature, and it will be even better with Mountain Lion this summer.At $99 this is a no brainer.If your have an iPad, this is a great add on.

PRO's:--For an Apple device, it's surprisingly similar to prices of other, competing set-top boxes--It's small--Sips electricity when in use; incredibly low use when asleep--Dead silent--Generates almost no heat--Makes viewing Netflix movies with Closed Captioning possible, even if your TV's built-in Netflix app refuses to do it--Menus are pretty easy to navigate around--Supports 1080p content when availableCON's:--Hey, it's an Apple device--it's locked down, so you're stuck with the options they provide (unless you jailbreak it)--Remote is so thin it's actually a bit difficult to use--Range of default, included remote is limited to a fairly short line-of-sight infared; can't really hide the AppleTV from view due to this flaw--No Amazon Streaming or Rentals--more of a push towards Apple and Netflix servicesBOTTOM Line:This is a nice little easy-to-use set-top box.  If you're planning to stream most of your content through one of the included service's apps, you're good to go.  You can stream media from OS X and Windows computers running iTunes.The Apple TV 3 doesn't have nearly the same sort of selection of options and expansion capabilities of something like the Roku platform, but it's not supposed to; it does what it does, and what it does, it does simply and reliably.
summary: Really Nice - if You Don't Want Amazon Streaming...

reviewText: ROKU LT vs APPLETV:The Good:AppleTV wins hands down on style.  The little box is about the same size as a ROKU LT, and a little heavier.  The on screen graphics are also laid out like ever other Apple product, clean, easy to understand.Roku on the other hand is much faster, have a bizillion types of content (even "hidden addable stations") that you can add later.  The UI is clumsy, sure - but so what when you have that kind of content made available to you for free!The Bad:AppleTV only allows a hookup with a optical interface or HDMI.  This would prove sorta tedious if your TV only has 1 HDMI port.  On ROKU you have a choice, HDMI or old school RCA (red, yellow, white) plugs.  AppleTV also seriously lacks any way to acccess any really cool information (apps)AppleTV:  NetFlix (paid) HuluPlus (paid) MLB.com (paid) NBA (paid) NHL (paid) Trailers (free) YouTube (free) Vimeo (free) Podcasts (free) Radio (free) PhotoStream (free) Flickr (free) WSJ Live (haven't checked this out yet)ROKU:  The world, literally!  You can add "unpublished" channels as easy as 1-2-3!The UGLY:AppleTV is slow!  I have it hooked up via HDMI and it buffers like crazy!  You can't listen to your iTunes music unless you pay $24.99 a year to mirror the music!  ROKU has a cool app called PLEX which will let you play all your iTunes music and Videos and other YouTube videos that you can "PlexIt" with the click of a button on your information bar!!  NO AMAZON PRIME?  WTF?ROKU requires a credit card for setup. It's also lightening fast compared to it's elder brother AppleTV.So, right now it's a toss-up with Roke edging out AppleTV to be my favorite, but I'll edit this review when I find out more.

Say what you will about Apple products but quality and ease of use will be two things.  I bought this for my 79 year old mother.  She connected it herself and watching her favorite movies right away. She uses her iPad to control the device and is saving money by canceling many premium cable services.  You can play with Android devices if you wish, but if you want to connect and use immediately, buy an Apple YV.

The Apple TV has some really cool features but this is the most disappointing apple product I've owned.  I consistently have connectivity issues, I hate the oversimplified remote and movies through the Apple store are a huge ripoff to both buy and rent.  The Apple TV costs $100 and then apple expects you to pay $6.99 to rent a movie that you can rent on RedBox for a $1.29 or $3.99 on Amazon.  The remote drives me nuts, it has essentially 4 buttons offering limited functionality and it's hideous and easily lost.  I like the Netflix streaming (although that has a fair share of connectivity issues) and the other nice applications.

The more I use this the more I love it. I am an owner of Roku boxes, the original Boxee Box, as well as the other common streaming options like a PS3, Smart TV, and Blu-Ray player.  Of all of the devices in our house the only one my wife uses is the Apple TV. I would say simplicity as well as reliability are the biggest reasons why she prefers it to the others.There are little things that I love about Apple TV that put it ahead of the competition. Let's start with the Apps first.  Apple TV has a very different interface for services like Hulu Plus and Netflix and it is in my opinion a superior one. Roku's Netflix App, for example, makes you scroll left to right with just a few titles in your instant queue showing each time. Apple TV shows all of your instant queue titles in one large screen. It is much easier to scroll down and find titles in the middle or bottom of a large queue.  Because of this different user interface all of the screens in the apps are easier to use and navigate.I also like that when you pick a something to watch it suggests several other titles that are similar to the one that you picked. This is very helpful in unlocking lesser known titles in the Netflix library.  Most apps do not come close to showing you all of the titles that are available for Netflix streaming. The suggestions open up the options to things you did not know were there. I love this feature as I have discovered titles that never show up in the main browsing menus.The other big plus is that the Apple TV always works. I cannot say this has been the case with the other boxes I own. I have lost track of the number of times I have had to reboot my Roku or Boxee Box to clear up a problem. This is more of an issue with Boxee but my Roku will often restart itself, lock-up in an app, or just be very slow in general navigation. I do not remember the last time I had to unplug the Apple TV for a hard reboot, if ever.I also love being able to push the up or down button on the remote to see where I am at in the program without having to press pause. I miss this function a lot on my Roku boxes. In addition to your place in the program this bar is useful when you are streaming Itunes related content. Apple TV has 8GB of internal flash storage and begins downloading an Itunes title when you start watching it.  This means you will not see a drop in image quality while watching a program even if your bandwidth becomes less. The progress bar shows you how much of the title is downloaded with a white bar.  If you are having streaming issues just pause the title and wait for the white bar to go ahead of your pause point. It is pretty rare when I need to do this but it is good to be able to see how much of the content is downloaded. If you do not finish a title and come back to it later the downloaded portion stays on the flash storage so streaming is always smooth.Of all the positives mentioned above I have not gotten into Air Play functions.  If you own an Ipad or Iphone, like my wife and I do, then this is another awesome feature. Simply put there are other options that offer more content but there are not many that do it in such simplistic and reliable fashion as this. If you own any other Apple products like a Macbook, Iphone, or Ipad then getting this little box would be a great choice. Even if you are not an Apple user there is a lot to love about Apple TV.
summary: Great Little Easy to Use Box

reviewText: The user interface is better than Roku (I have that also). I am VERY disappointed that Apple tv does not support Pandora.
summary: Apple TV does not support Pandora

reviewText: This is my second Apple TV and along with the mirroring on Mountain Lion makes it a must have home theater component.  They recently added Hulu+ and I am betting that more will come as broadcasters realize that with mirroring available they might as well join the parade.Easy setup via wifi or ethernet.  Fast interface which provides a lot of extra functionality with users existing Apple centric media libraries.  Streams photos and music like a charm.
summary: Simple and functional at a reasonable price

reviewText: This is now more than just a hobby for Apple.  I use it to watch video from my iPad or my iPhone all the time.  I rent movies on it.  I love using the Netflix and Hulu apps.  The HBO Go app has been great to watch my HBO series.  I can not wait to see what is added next.  It also is an Apple product which means it just works.  I plugged it in and a few minutes later it was working.

We all have iPhones or iPods and Windows machines with iTunes on them. I installed AirParrot on my Windows Asus laptop and have had no issues whatsoever this this. The video and sound quality is stellar for Netflix, Hulu, iTunes (movies, radio and more). Plug it in, go through the setup and BOOM! You're ready to rock n' roll.Must have if you are already or plan to join in the Apple ecosystem.
summary: Great Video and Sound. Easy to configure.

reviewText: We received this as a Christmas gift and totally love it! Set-up was fast & simple, including the network connection to our home wi-fi. I love the AirPlay feature which lets us stream to our HDTV from our iPads. I like being able to stream photos and music for a screen saver; it's fun having a rotating slide show of our family, friends and favorite pics.  We have also used it to rent an HD movie from iTunes and the download time and play quality were excellent. We don't have a Netfix or HuluPlus account, so have not tried those options. However, we also have a networked Sony BluRay DVD player we use to watch TV programs and movies on Amazon Prime and find them similar in quality and pricing. The advantage of AmazonPrime is the free content, i.e., Downton Abbey seasons 1 & 2 are free on Amazon Prime, but you have to purchase them on AppleTV. We also have Comcast Xfinity and get free programming that we would have to pay for on the AppleTV, i.e., Homeland TV series.  I think AppleTV would be a better product if it included AmazonPrime, but I'm happy with it. I just wish we could combine all these products into one box so we'd have fewer remotes to keep track of!
summary: Nice Edition to Our Media Center

reviewText: We use this with a 50" tv in our office for meetings, etc.  My only disappointment is that my Macbook Pro is one half generation too old to work without using Parrot.  Parrot and my old Macbook don't run fast enough to provide some of the video or complex Keynote slides without either lower graphic quality or delay.  Others in my office with newer laptops have no problem, and everything works just fine.

When I first wrote this review I gave it 2/5.  I've since upped to 3/5.The good:+Easy to setup.+Airplay from OSX works great.  Super easy to get set up.  I don't have an iPhone so can't tell you how well it works from your phone, but imagine it's just as easy.+If you can play it in iTunes, you can easily stream it to your TV.+The remote is nice.The bad:-If you can play it in iTunes, you can easily stream it to your TV.  Yes I did list it as both good and bad.  The problem is that iTunes doesn't support really that many file formats.Want to play a video in MKV file?  It's a popular video format, but nope sorry.Want to play a FLAC?  It's open source and more popular than Apple's lossless format, but nope sorry.It makes for a really crappy user experience when you have to convert formats for the sake of Apple's prudness.  Converting audio is not that big of a deal.  However re-encode HD video in to an mp4, can take considerable time.  Although I've figured out how to encode the video to mp4, and the even faster method of remuxing the video (assuming it's using the proper encoding), it's still more time (and possibly cost) than the non-technical will want to put in to it.  Sometimes the Apple way, is not the best way.-The lack of apps.  It would seem that this is a killer time for Apple to dominate the living room.  However they haven't opened up the Apple TV up to developers, so don't expect to find specialty music apps like Pandora.  However you could always play such services via Airplay either on OSX or iOS.-Does not recognize different wireless frequencies with the same broadcast name.  I've always found this kind of odd, and it's the same way in OSX.  If you want to chose between 2.4 Ghz or 5 Ghz wireless you must name each differently.  If you're going to steam high def video, or use airplay to your tv you probably want the 5 Ghz band properly set up.-The interface feels old and dated.-Not all Macs or Hackintoshs support Airplay video mirroring.  Luckily an app like AirParrot will allow you to use it.  Airplay sound should work regardless.Conclusion:Overall it's a stylish little box, and you could probably do worse.  If you're happy with iTunes, and can deal with how Apple restricts you, or already have your entire media library in iTunes, then this is right up your alley and you'll love this.  If you buy content from the iTunes store and want a way to play it on your tv easily, you'll love this.  If you have an iOS device and can Airplay stuff to it, you'll love this.  If you're just a huge fanboy, you'll love this.For the rest the lack of choice seems less than ideal.  If you have a large media library that is not iTunes friendly you should spend your money else where.  Similar boxes, like the Roku 3 (but any Roku 2 box really) have a lot more apps, and can play nearly any music or video format with Plex media server.  A lot more choice and cost the same or less.  The Roku 3 should also soon support the non-Apple Airplay called "Miracast".After using the Apple TV it for a few days, I'm probably going to keep it.  I find enough uses for it, and have invested enough time in to it to figure out some of the technical hurdles.  I do enjoy Airplay, but wonder if it's really worth the cost of admission.  However that seems to be what this device is, it was meant for you to use some kind of other Apple device to interact with it.  It just, feels odd.  But when you think about it, it should bring unlimited possibilities.I find it hard to recommend.  I feel it's primarily aimed at non-technical people who don't know any better, like most Apple products.  However if you are on the more technical side and have the patience to deal with the technical issues it can also serve you well.  It doesn't seem to fit the middle ground so well.

As a streaming media player you have to let your computer on to play content, no USB HDD support, it's just interesting for iOS devices that support Airplay. Without jailbreak, i wouldn't recommend it! Do Yourself a favour and buy a WD Live Streaming Media Player for the money!

Better than a dvd player, poorer than all other streamers.There are just better streamers out there. I worked at an R&D; lab where we reviewed, analyzed and compared various external and on board streamers including Google, Boxee, Samsung, LG, Vizio, and Apple. What I landed on personally, was that all other streamers could play more. Different media services have different catalogs so when getting a streamer, the most important feature is that it can play as many as possible.I have to give it one star extra because the remote is nice. Probably the best non-keyboard remote.
summary: A streamer only a mac-person could love.

reviewText: Excelente producto, lo recibí a tiempo y sin ningún problema. Funciona muy bien, lo compré con los cables HDMI y óptico para audio.

First let me start by saying i have the Roku in the basement and this for the bedroom TV. Simply put the Roku does more; like FREE streaming your entire library of music AND video via the Plex app. There are also way more channels for the Roku. With that said you also have to have itunes match to use the music from your mac. Just another apple product that nickel and dimes you for something that a competitor product does better.I am actually a little disappointed in this. BUT if you have match already and lots of movies on itunes i guess this will be just fine. Just saying though the Roku is a better and cheaper buy...
summary: Not as Good as the Roku

reviewText: I bought Apple Tv as I had other Apple products and thought it would be easier and fun to play movies/songs directly on my TV via my iphone/ipad or MacBook.. It all worked fine for few days, but after a while there was a huge lag, and movies and songs will hang in between showing buffering ! The movies will not play smoothly.Looks like a complete waste of money.. Will not recommend buying it.

I bought the Apple TV to stream my amazon prime and xfinity tv videos to the tv. It cannot be done, not even with the mirroring feature. I'm returning the Apple TV since I have no use for it. I don't need Netflix or Hulu since I have amazon prime and iTunes is too expensive.

I bought this as an upgrade to my old first generation 160GB Apple TV. In some ways, it is an inferior product. I get to that at the end. I'll talk about what I like first.The good: The unit is small, light and doesn't act as a space heater like the old hard drive based Apple TVs. It has a pretty easy to use interface and supports full HD (1080p) video. Airplay is a great feature! I prefer hard line connections for security and the unit supports fast GBit Ethernet. I'm a heavy iTunes user, so the content side works fine for me, but I have heard complaints about access to other content providers.The bad: The new Apple TVs do not support iTunes Extras! WTF!!!!!! You can watch movies, but you can't watch the iTunes Extras that come with them on iTunes. One of the most ridiculously stupid things Apple has ever done. Nobody wants to watch a movie on their TV and then go sit at their computer to watch the bonus features. Also, the lack of internal storage means your computer must be on and iTunes open for the Apple TV to work, or you have to subscribe to iTunes Match (at extra cost). With the improvement in flash storage, this thing should have at least 8GB to store music and a little video so you don't have to boot up the computer just to hear some tunes while you're cooking dinner. While the interface isn't bad, it is inferior to the interface on the old Apple TV. The older version was much more fluid and easy to use.

I got this to use the Airplay feature.  I have a media hub in my house so the ability to buy or rent movies/tv shows off iTunes wasn't a big deal for me.Apple doesn't tell you this, or at least advertise this fact, but you need a 2011 Macbook or newer.  If you have an older Mac it will not let you do mirroring, and I'm not sure it will even let you use airplay.  Luckily I have a new MBP, so that was not an issue for me, but just wanted to let other people know as I have seen some people pretty upset it didn't work with their current Mac setup.I really like how easy it is to use.  It took mere minutes to set up and get situated with my iTunes account.  The only complaint I'd have about this stage is the remote takes forever to scroll through all the letters and symbols to enter your user name and password, but thats not really Apple's fault, well kind of, but nothing a nice remote with keyboard wouldn't fix.Airplay works really well, I was very impressed with the speed and sound quality of the streaming from the bedroom into the living room.  I haven't tried streaming anything 1080p because the only movies I had on my iTunes currently were 720p, but those streamed well without any hitches.My only complaint would be with the mirroring.  It works flawlessly as far as picture quality and sound quality.  The gripe I have, and maybe this is just my problem and I haven't figured out how to work around it......but to move anything on the screen you need to actually be looking at the computer and physically moving it.  I guess it was more my fault, because if there is no mouse or keyboard directly connected to it, how is it supposed to know its supposed to move?  I guess I figured something in the Apple TV itself would sync up and allow you to use the remote or something to move around the screen.  It would not, so to change what I was watching as far as a MKV file that iTunes didn't support I had to go into the other room, click on everything, hit play and then walk back out to the living room.  Not a huge deal, because the picture quality and sound was great, when you connect them the sound actually won't come out of your computer anymore and will go right to your speakers so thats nice, which makes me think there must be some way to get a mouse or something working on the screen.Overall I'm pretty happy, but just a few minor complaints.  Its still a great purchase and makes it a lot easier to stream music from my computer room rather than hooking up my iPod to the stereo.
I hate that there is no update for netfilx to have post -play, it also has problems loading and playing pretty often

I have found this to be an amazing product for home use to streaming photos, movies, music throughout the house.  But my pleasent suprise came when I started using it for business use in keynote or powerpoint presentations wirelessley from my ipad, or even iphone.Super easy set-up and mobility.

In general I have had a love hate relationship with Apple and my Apple TV. When it works, man it works great. When you interact with iTunes Netflix- the things the Apple has a good partnership with, it's fantastic. When I want to airplay hulu...I'm not having so much fun. When I want to use my iPad to airplay content available on my PC that I own...I'm not having so much fun.I've downloaded several apps to try to compensate for Apple's lack of integration and plug ins and I cannot get around it. When I use my Xbox 360 for content I have a very good experience, but Apple just only wants to let me use MY content the way THEY want. I do not appreciate that very much. I am done investing my money in Apple and once the market catches up to them (which they will) in phone technology and tablet, a lot of people will see why Microsoft dominated for so many years.

Just so you know I like this product a lot. But I bought this mainly for AirPlay and I was greatly disappointed when I found out in order to use AirPlay for games you must have a iPhone 4s or later or a iPad 2 or later. Unfortunately for me I have a iPhone 4 and a iPad 1 so it really sucks. So make sure you have one.

We have been looking for a way to cut cable costs for a while and decided to try Apple TV WE LOVE IT!We subscribed to Netflix for $8.99 a month and Hulu Plus for the same price, and were able to cut our cable package to the local basic channels and increased the speed of our internet. Wireless connection is great. I love that I can listen to Pandora from my iphone through the Apple TV onto my TV, my kids love it, especially the Netflix, they never run out of things to watch and we have rented several movies from the Apple Store, super user friendly.We are actually going to buy two more, one for our bedroom and for the kids basement playroom.  Make sure you have an HDMI cable, it doesn't come with one and you will need it to make it work, we bought one on here for less than $10. It updates itself regularly, a notice comes on the screen for the update and it takes about 2 minutes.We had considered the Boxy Box, but decided to try this because the cost was better, and honestly we are just Mac people, but this product is awesome!

when i first got my Apple TV, I was impressed by the way it connects with my other apple devices, allowing me to stream music from my ipod to my TV (very useful at parties), i was also impressed with some of the internet features, such as youtube you could access on your TV. However as i looked for more features i became a little disheartened, the majority of the content on the apple TV required an additional fee to 'rent' it.In the end i felt like i had bought a device which does things that any PC can do, except on my TV, and i thought to myself... 'is that worth 100?I do not feel that this is anywhere near the quality level that other Apple products are, such as the iphone or macbook.
summary: Good, but not quite the quality you expect from Apple.

reviewText: A week ago I would have given this 4 stars.  But then I bought a Roku and realized just how limited the Apple TV is.  The Roku allows me to access Amazon Prime movies and Pandora; the only use I have for Apple TV is Netflix, which the Roku also does.  Basically, Roku does everything Apple TV does plus a whole lot more.

I have wanted to get an apple tv for the longest time due to the seamless experience with iTunes, and my iPhone and iPad. The one thing that kept me from getting it was that the previous version was only 720p. Well now that apple released the 1080p apple TV I finally took the jump and bought one. I can truly say I am very happy with it. With the apple TV I can access my music thats on my iMac, and with airplay i can start a movie on my iphone, or iPad and finish it on my TV. I have a ROKU and have enjoyed it for the last few years, but I always felt like it was missing something. I use my iPhone and iPad all the time so having a devices that seamlessly work together was important to me. Netflix is now also in 1080p so I don't just have to use my PS3 to get that kind of quality. For less than one hundred bucks with all the functionality that this little box does it is very worth it. If only it had amazon like the Roku this would be perfect.
summary: Apple TV now in 1080p and looks amazing!

reviewText: The remote makes me want to smash my head against the wall. It is so tiny, I lose it all the time. In fact, it may be the smallest remote I've ever seen.  It is so slim that it falls into the abyss of my couch through the smallest of crevices. I can't really speak to the quality of this device as the remote is always missing. So I basically have an attractive looking box next the tv that that just sits there taunting me.
summary: The remote is very small and annoying...

reviewText: Update (Dec 7, 2013)Since version 6.02 Netflix has become unwatchable during prime time on the Apple TV. It used to be the best at streaming HD shows on Netflix. Not anymore. All my other device stream Netflix much better during the same prime time viewing slot. Lots of others are reporting the same issue on Apple TV forum on discussions.apple.com.Until this is resolved ... I will be using my PS3.-------Better YouTube experience here than on Google TV,That itself should tell you everything you need to know.The fact that it starts Netflix and get you to their main page in less than 3 seconds ... And plays everything flawlessly is merely icing on the cake.Bravo.Now some minor quibbles.- remote blows.- smithsonian stream stops in the middle- no Amazon prime
summary: Apple TV and Netflix broke it with version 6.02

reviewText: It was simple to setup but it is a major downgrade from the first generation.I am over the lack of local storage (no HDD). I setup a mac mini as a media server for my home. But, it is still cumbersome to use with streaming data on a home network. It wants to force you into using iCloud and a paid Match service instead of using the content I have right there. Yes, you can go through 5 menu selections to get to your local content but that makes most of the front screen menu buttons just clutter unless you are committed to streaming everything from Apple.The organization of content is just bad. Every season of television shows gets its own listing instead of every show; that makes the listing way too long. Does the streaming TV shows have any real organization and why does it not show all of my old purchases?Furthermore, I am not sure if it will update my media server automatically like the first generation did. Can you even buy music/music videos on this??I repaired my first generation Apple TV and turned off all syncing. Now my system makes sense; it is simple, efficient and keeps my server updated without extra work on my end. I am sad to lose the video upgrades though. But, I do get analogue audio outputs for my stereo.If you have (almost) no content, do not care to use it for music purchases, want to stream everything over the web, it may not be a bad choice if you have never used the first gen. I just have trouble seeing how it could be a good choice for anyone. See if you can get a first generation.Update: I kept this and software upgrades have improved it. Also, I have become more comfortable with streaming everything. I still do not like that I have to pay to listen to music I already paid for. Also, the menus really should be in alphabetical order.

I've bought and returned two of these. I also have two Roku boxes, and just bought a Chromecast.  I'm on a quest to find a way to stream Time Warner video on demand, which I thought would be possible by streaming the TWC websit via Airplay, but the video is choppy and the resolution sucks. I see no reason to buy the ATV over the Roku other than desktop mirroring. Virtually all the limited iPad app content is available via Roku for less money, and there's much more content. The Apple UI is somewhat prettier, with no ads, but that's about it. I'm disappointed that after all this time Apple has not paid more attention to the ATV. Rumor has it that a new version will be released in October, so perhaps that will make it worthwhile. But until that happens, I really can't recommend it.

The device is simply a portal through which to purchase recorded content. It is not a substitute for cable or satellite, unfortunately, as there appears to be no live content except maybe pay-per-view sporting events. You can jailbreak the device and get live web streaming (in fact, there is no built in browser) but that brings headaches of its own.They should be giving these away, not selling them.
summary: Ok if you need it, I guess

reviewText: There will be some for whom this is a great product.  If you live in a studio apartment, and your Apple TV box is a few feet away from your router, then it might work well.  But our situation is that the router is in another room, about 25 feet away, partially blocked by a wall.  The result is a train-wreck.  Initially, it didn't work at all (well, it worked for the first few days, then not at all.)  I used the utility Wifi Stumbler (not supported by Apple) to detect interference from other routers, then went and changed the channel on which my router was broadcasting.  Now, it works, sort of.  Netflix movies start and stop regularly.  A 30 minute t.v. show generally takes close to an hour to watch, and there's no rhyme or reason to when the show will stop, and when it will start again.  It obviously destroys the viewing experience, particularly when you have a dramatic scene or sequence, to have it freeze for two minutes, start up for another minute, and freeze again.  YouTube is completely hit or miss -- some stuff just won't play at all.Support was of limited assistance.  I was given several helpful suggestions about how I could spend several hundred more dollars buying additional components to add more routers, drill holes in my walls and run huge cables through them so that the Apple TV could be wired instead of wireless.Thanks guys, but that's not what you advertised, and not what I bought.  What I'm left with is the equivalent of a radio that only works if you're actually in the radio station.

When it works, it's great.  But when it doesn't, it's a headache and very frustrating.  Apple does not seem to want to support this device very well.  I try to access my video files on my computer and my Apple TV says to turn "Home Sharing" on in my computer.  But it's already on.  How to I turn it "more" on?  I turn it off, then on again.  Then I get "Error 5599".  What does that mean?  So I Google it and get to an Apple support bulletin board.  I find that dozens of others are wondering the same thing, all very frustrated.  Why doesn't Apple monitor their own bulletin boards and help us out?  I guess when you're the big gorilla in the room, you make the rules.  And if there are errors or glitches, you just call them "industry standards".

AppleTV is a great product, and I won't re-hash the product itself here. I had the 720P version and this is the 1080P version, but still just as great otherwise. No, what I found important here is that with this Apple product, I started to do as I always do and buy directly from Apple's web site.I was on a break at work, I had a credit card already set up with Apple, and I was ready to buy. So I logged in, put it in my cart, went to check out, but they wanted the security code for my Apple/Barclay card I have on file with them. Fair enough... a good security measure I suppose. But I'm at work and my card is at home where I keep it safely tucked away. I never use it for anything but Apple store purchases and I don't carry a balance due to it's usurious interest rate. So, without the code, I have to log off and leave the item in my cart for later.Later that evening, at home, I tried to complete my purchase. But when I logged in, Apple had forgotten that I put a product in my cart. What AppleTV? :D  So I added it back to my cart, noted the $99 plus tax price, free 5-7 day shipping and the need for someone to be around to sign for the delivery unless I planned ahead and did a release form (which you can't do until you get shipping notification.) Eh! Not a huge deal but a bit of a pain and kinda slow. Then for some reason, I stopped before entering my credit card security code and completing the sale... it occurred to me to hop over to Amazon and see if they had this item. Of course they do!Not only does Amazon have the item, it is the same price, but they offer 2-day Prime free shipping, one-click ordering with no hassle or extra verification step, and no hassle with having to be around to sign for it. And not only did I get 2-day Prime shipping for free, the fact that it came via ONTRACK means I actually got it in 1 day instead of 2.I think Apple's online store is great. And I don't have a problem with a certain amount of caution in the security department. But I've ordered several items there with that same Barclay card, had all shipments sent to the same address on file, so how it it necessary to have to enter to security code from the back of the physical card and sign for the delivery on an order like this? A multi-thousand dollar computer shipped to a different address, you bet. But I think some sense and convenience has to come into play.Thank you Amazon for once again proving this is the best place on earth to shop. No, I'm not a shill and own no interest in the company. I just like shopping online, getting 2-day free delivery and not having to fight traffic or lines to get anything anymore.

First off, I am a diehard Apple fan.  I have two Apple computers, iphone and an ipod.  Apple TV is a cool product (as Apple always delivers on) and it does run smooth without any bugs, but when it comes it watching all your web content on one simple device, it falls very short.  I enjoy watching Netflix on it but can't believe there are no options for things like Hulu Plus, HBO GO, Crackle, or any other website that carries video content (ABC, NBC, PBS, etc.) There are better options for an all in one web-to-TV devices like the Roku, Xbox, Playstation and most blue ray players.Save your money and look else were on this Apple product.
summary: Great Design BUT Very Limited Selection

reviewText: Hope Apple catches up with the mainstream Blueray players with built in WiFi. This is lacking so many apps - why is there no Amazon InstantVideo?!?!?  If this had a built-in blue-ray player without changing the size too much, I might be swayed... but unfortunately, this had to go back.

I don't see any reason why $100 should be spent for this product.There is NO browser compared to Google TV or Basic Samsung OS in TV. You cannot install any APP in Apple TV.I have lot of apple products, but this one really is poorly done.
summary: Not a useful device even though you have other Apple products

reviewText: I'm sorry to be the bad guy!Tried to "go Apple" and ended up with sour grapes.The Family is Apple... I'm the PC Geek who finally thought we could use this for 1080 HD with Apple and Netflix... knowing Amazon Prime wouldn't work.Sure it is pretty... and sure it is a slick well thought out User Interface... If it only worked properly!Every damn time you try to use after selecting a program in HD it has the infamous "Change your Cable Error"... which of course is nothing to do with the cable and is an Apple equipment problem.And... I've tried everything to keep the family happy... just isn't working.[...]My take... Buy the Roku/WD/Android Products that work... dump Apple and be in the open platform world.I tried!If anyone want's mine... they can have it.
summary: A Geek tried to convert to the dark side.... and failed.

reviewText: Update: Streaming audio to the Apple TV works for a while, but many times after about 10-30 minutes, the audio stream breaks up, becomes intermittent, or stops altogether. Neither the cause nor the solution are apparent. Altogether, this device is marginally usable junk.We've been using a Roku to stream Netflix and occasionally buy TV shows from Amazon.The Apple TV setup was simple. Streaming audio and video from an iPad worked pretty well after some fiddling. Apparently you have to start the playback (audio or video) and then send it to the ATV, which means it always starts a few seconds into whatever you're playing. Mirroring the iPad works well.The iPad slideshow, however, apparently cannot be mirrored or streamed to the ATV, which is inconsistent and irritating.We then tested another function: renting a movie. The Apple TV interface is terrible for entering usernames, passwords, and credit card numbers. After trying several times and failing, despite having entered everything correctly as far as we could tell, we rented the movie through the iPad. It immediately began downloading to the iPad. It would take nearly two hours to download, and then we would have 24 hours to watch it. That wouldn't work well with our schedule. The rented movie can only be played on the device through which it was rented. I suppose it might have streamed through the ATV.So I found the same movie on Amazon at half the price for twice the time, rented it through the Roku, and watched it. To reduce wireless traffic, I put the iPad movie download on pause and let it expire. There's apparently no way to cancel it outright.I probably won't try to rent or buy any media through the AppleTV, nor movies or TV shows through the iTunes store. The offerings seem to be limited, overpriced, overly limited, and clumsily handled.Playing videos and music through Airplay to the home sound system is very handy, and that's the main reason I got the ATV. The mirroring sounds interesting but ends up being marginally useful.
summary: Airplay is nice, when it works. Other features not ready for prime time.

reviewText: Went to stream a movie from iTunes store and got a message that my movie would be ready for viewing in 2 hours and 30 minutes. What? Obviously decided to do something else in the meantime; when I came back to the Apple TV the next night expecting my movie to have been buffered, I got the same message. What? Have no problem watching movies stream over the same network to other devices like a PS3 or Wii. Basically don't use it now as Netflix and Amazon Instant Video works fine on other devices.Terrible remote. After considerable effort got access to my iPhoto library but viewing was so clumsy never used it again.
summary: Apple missed the target on this device.

reviewText: I've had the roku 2 xs for about one year and have been very happy with it. I purchased Apple TV not as a replacement but to work along side my roku. I wanted to access itunes content and youtube. Sadly I could not log into youtube or my itunes accounts AT ALL. I checked online and others are having this problem. The way to fix it is to buy a new router - I will not because my $200 router is ony 4 months old. Its not my router it ATV, my router works fine with everything else. The two reason I bought it I could not get, very disappointing.ATV is also extremely SLOW taking nearly a full minuet for netflix and hulu to load. The roku interface might be simple looking in comparison to ATV but its much faster. Lastly the Apple TV remote is so freakin tiny - like it was made for tiny people in some tiny alternate universe. If you sat on the remote without any clothes on it might slip up your butt unnoticed (well maybe not:). I really wanted to like the ATV but it was useless for me and I sent it back.

One issue with this device is with the range, I am about 50ft from my wireless router, causing disconnections and loading issues. The apple TV also randomly resets during play, which causes me to lose my position in whatever I was watching and I have to fast forward back to where I was. Also, every now and then the apple TV will give me the error "Netflix cannot be reached at this time", and I have to reset the device. If I could return the device I would and try my luck with a Roku. I love apple products, so its safe to say that this was a disappointment for me. I may have received a defective device also, but I believe I am past the return/replacement period.

What is is: an extremely easy to use device to connect iTunes or other apple devices, wired ethernet or wirelessly, to your HDTV and stereo.What it is not: completely pleasing.  The single biggest problem is that it's limited to 30 frames per second.  It also limits the number of fields updated. It means you notice a jerkiness to the display.  Motions are not natural.  The sound is fine; it's the drop in frame rate that loses points.In my opinion, it impacts the video presentation making a movie less enjoyable (the reason for the low rating)....stick to DVDs or an HDMI cable from a good video card in your computer connected to your TV.A BD-DVD can provide 59.9 fields per second (like old-time tv) at full HD (a field is a still image that fills half the lines of resolution of a frame).  The Apple HD video format does not provide the full bandwidth.  Running a video encoded for apple-tv on iTunes vs the original DVD, the dropout is immediately noticeable. (The Apple TV supports up to H.264/AVC high profile 4.0; it is suggested that to cover 1080p correctly at least 4.1 is necessary - which, btw, iphone 4 apparently supports.)The wireless network this was on is not highly loaded - it has plenty of bandwidth (802.11-n).Having said the above I intend to use this heavily over the next month as an audio node and based on that may revise this review again.
summary: Great audio, clear picture, but motion is jerky

reviewText: I generally LOVE Apple products. I HATE this piece of junk. I'd call it worse than that but this IS a public forum. If I want to listen to my itunes on this, I can. Yeah, but I don't, because my music sounds much better on my Bose iDock than it does on my TV speakers.  If I want to watch youtube on this, I can, no problem. But what I really wanted it for was to watch netflix and to interface with my MacBook Pro. OF COURSE, these are the two things it WILL NOT DO!I can't even open Netflix most of the time. Or it is slow. Or stops and starts.When I use airplay, so that I can use the TV as a big screen for my computer, it packs up on me and just quits doing it. Airplay. Should call it Airpoop. Cuz it Airpoops out on me all the time!I returned the first Apple TV I had as defective, because even Apple support couldn't help me fix it. Now with the second one I am just giving up.  This is a shameful product. SHAME SHAME SHAME on you Apple! You charge a lot of money for your products and I LOVE my MacBook Pro and my iPhone, but this is a MASSIVE FAIL!I wouldn't be so mad about this if my expectations weren't so high. This is an APPLE product! It should be awesome! IT'S NOT!I'm going to go buy a Roku. Airpoop on you, Apple!

WORTHLESS if you don't pay for Cable TV -Apps Require Cable TV Subscription verification.Apple TV is worthless if you want to use apps!.... All but Netflix or paid video like HULU need a Cable Provider Verification!!!Apple TV just added WatchABC app and you need to have a cable provider to use the app. ABC is a network channel and is free to people who have antenna tv and don't have or can't afford to pay for cable tv.  But on Apple TV the WatchABC app you need to have proof that you pay for cable TV and on top of that AppleTV does not even offer all the cable TV providers including DirectTV, Dish or TimeWarner cable. So this app is WORTHLESS to most people even if they have cable TV or not.Most of the Apps on AppleTV are like this. WatchEspn, MLB, FoxNow, all three Disney Channel apps all require cable TV verification. They want proof you pay for cable tv even for apps where one does not need cable TV to watch the channel.If I had cable what would I need the app for when I can watch it On Demand on my TV...WatchABC app is free on an iPad or other devices but not on AppleTV.So is FoxNow, NBC players but not free on Apple TV.In my opinion Apple TV sucks. Pretty worthless if you want to use apps.The apps Apple TV has are so few with several in chinese or japanese so if you don't speak those languages you can't use those apps.AppleTV is only good for Netflix, Hulu, and  iTunes purchases.Instead buy a Google ChromeCast device USB port device for $35 and get the same mirroring of apps as Apple AirPlay does. Much cheaper and the picture quality is fantastic. Just mirror your apps from your mobile, iPad, Android or computer device to your TV...Then you don't need cable TV subscription verification.Don't buy this unit.
summary: WORTHLESS if you don't pay for Cable TV -Apps Require Cable TV Subscription Verification! Get Google Chromecast instead. Cheaper

reviewText: I bought this over a year ago (not the new, new one) mainly for Netflix and photo/video sharing between my MBP, Ipod, Ipad, and my Panasonic 7.1 system. I used to have a wobbly TV dinner table next to my 65" Panny Plasma for a laptop to connect via a HDMI.First, the Netflix video is spot on. Looks just as good as standard DVD. Last year, I experienced many video stoppages, and skips, and generally bad video performance. They must have fixed these problems because I have had no issue for almost a year.The bad, while you can stream video from Ipod and Ipad to ATV - you cannot stream them from your Imac or your MBP. YES I know you can use silly Itunes - however, I HATE ITUNES. I refuse to use Itunes because it is too controlling - it wants to become the end all be all media center. I deleted Itunes shortly after getting my MBP because it would not allow me to burn any of my music without my credit card info. It was my music I paid for previously and I do not give out my credit card info!Sadly, without the capability to hookup to my MBP, I can only give this product a 2 out of 5. (1) for ease of connectivity with my Ipad and Ipod, and (1) for the clarity of video on my screen when using Netflix. It is seamless with Netflix.
summary: Great for Netflix - Thats about it.

reviewText: I like this device but I am upset that I cannot stream Amazon Prime.This makes me so mad and it is such a big deal that I will NEVER recommend this to my friends and family.
OK my 1st review was negative and I'm sorry for that. i had to get professional installment help and i got to admit I'm satisfied, good product so far

This is great if you want to do netflix and basic web app stuff but if youre buying this for the airplay mirroring features say far far away. I upgraded to Mountain lion and purchased this apple tv to have wireless mirroring of my macbook pro screen and it DOES NOT work well. And before you ask yes, it was set up right. I've been in networking IT for 7 years and i can set it up. The fact is apple dropped the ball on the software to do airplay.
summary: Never trust that it'll work like they say

reviewText: This product is severely limited in capabilities compared to a Roku.  It has the two major streaming apps, Netflix and Hulu, but that is about it.  I would not even consider this if you rarely purchase or rent anything from the iTunes store.  I purchased it strictly as a subscription based streaming device and am utterly disappointed.It does include AirPlay capabilities to expand the amount of content that the device is able to play, but this is only good in theory.  In reality AirPlay is an extremely finicky protocol and rarely works without any stuttering.  As it relies on communications back and forth between the sending device (iPad, iPhone, etc), it unnecessarily clogs up your network with traffic.  What they need to do is create dedicated apps for the Apple TV so that it takes out this intermediate process.I cannot recommend this device at all unless they bump up the apps available at least tenfold.
Absolutely amazing product!Well made and truly connects your Mac computers to your TV. If you are a Mac person, the Apple TV is a must have product!

Amazon does so many things well so I was surprised that they sold a product which has so many widgets minus Amazon Prime.  Netflix works great but Amazon Prime is my other mode of watching tv.  If someone tells you that you can watch Amazon Prime by airplay through later generation iphones and ipads, well I tried this and the picture was grainy and the connection kept getting lost.  When Apple adds Prime, my rating will be upped to 4 or 5 stars.  In the meantime, I hope that many of you put some  pressure on Apple.  Think of it like this:  What would Apple be saying to Microsoft and what would be saying, as well, if itunes was not on Windows computers?
summary: It would be great if it has Amazon Prime

reviewText: Apple just needs to cozy up with Bezos over at Amazon and get the Amazon video on this device!  Then, it will be perfect!

Cons: No pandora. No amazon prime. No vudu.Pros: looks good. Simple to get up and running.I've been using roku forever. Got this for the wife to easily throw up the ipad screen onto the tv.I find that Apple is trying to do too much with this. I don't have a choice as to where I listen to my music - pandora or where I watch my movies - amazon and vudu. They'd like me to do everything on iTunes. If that's you then this is for you.We are now using this as an expensive way to mirror our ipad to the tv.Roku even has a YouTube app which is what we'd originally needed to mirror to the tv. And the small memory stick form factor is perfect - less wires in the living room.

even with wired internet buffers a lot while playing netflix. Never happened with my xbox which is right next to it and is connected wirelessly to the internet. Airplay video playback on tv has very poor resolution. I don't know what I was expecting but performance was not upto my expectations.

For $95 this device is just amazing.  The Netflix interface is even better than Netflix itself.  It has groupings by Characters and the normal groups like on the iOS devices or direct internet link.  I bought an optical audio to coaxial cable converter (<$20) and connected that to a receiver so I can control music from the iMac/iTunes. I can even control the music via the Apple Remote app.  Another unsung feature is the ability to play movies from the iMac.  That works great.  Of course interfacing with your iTunes account directly is a possibility also.  The remote is the classic Jobs simplistic design and works great also.  It powers down automatically.  Nothing but great things to say about AppleTV.

I bought two of these to use around the office for mirroring desktops on MacOS, iOS, and Windows 7 to large monitors.  This has to be one of the most effortless technology hoops that I ever had to jump through.  I was all prepped for having to do a bunch of research and trial & error, but it was about a 10 minute operation from unboxing to mirroring.  Wow.  Thank you, Apple, for making my life easier.  Thank you, AirParrot, for making it easy to run AirPlay off a PC.Now, as a media device, I don't like the dependence on iTunes, limited media file playback, or the lack of an Amazon Prime player.  I also find it annoying that the homes screen has extremely limited customization ... you can move some of the icons (!??).  But I did not buy these devices for media purposes (however most people will).  If you are buying these only for the AirPlay feature, then it is well worth the price.

I have been going back and forth for a while now on whether or not to purchase the Apple TV. Now that I just received it I love it! The Picture is great, the portability is perfect. Easy to set up and now I can FINALLY watch my Itunes Movies on my TV. I do not really enjoy watching movies on my laptop or PC. I have 2 negatives about it.1. Not that many apps. Would like to see more added.2. More descriptions for what I get with each App. Example: MLBTV. It gives me 2 options to buy from but I am not sure what I get with each.Otherwise its a great buy and cheaper from Amazon than via Apple.

I owned a Sony Blue-ray (model: BDV T58) with wifi function.  I recently purchased this Apple TV because I want to mirror my Mac Air and iPad screen to the Sony Brevia TV (no wifi function).  So, after comparing these two products, here is my observation.Sony Blue-ray has many more channels by 10 times compares to Apple TV, including the unpaid/no-need-for-subscription Crackle (ad. occurs every 15 mins).  Also, if you have Amazon Prime, you can watch Amazon Instant Movie on Blue-ray, but not on Apple TV.  The only movie channels on Apple are iTune and Netflix.  If you like TV shows, Apple TV also has Hulu Plus that costs just as much as Netflix online streaming.  But that is pretty much it for Apple TV.One huge advantage of having an Apple TV is that you can actually use keyboard to enter the name of the youtube video or name of the movie/TV shows or whatever.  If you own a bluetooth Apple keyboard, then you can easily connect it to your Apple TV (it is a no brainer, super easy to do).  Don't underestimate this feature, because a lot of people, including myself, have already given up on searching videos on YouTube or Netflix using a Blue-ray, because it is a pain in the neck to use remote control to enter each letter of the keyword or song/movie/video title.If you have subscribed to Netflix and have high-speed internet at home (download speed is greater than 10mbps), then Apple TV gives you super HD quality picture (1080) when you watch a movie.  The blue-ray I own is visibly not as great as Apple TV when it comes to HD movies on Netflix.  However, if your internet is slow when you use Apple TV, then multiple problems occur when you watch HD movies, including in-synchronization between audio and video, video stops frequently and screen turns black, video lags and so on.  One solution might be to use ethernet cable instead of wifi.The set-up for Apple TV is easy - all you need is a HDMI cable (purchase separately) and a TV that has HDMI input.  The mirroring function of your iPad/Macbook/iPhone/iPod to your TV can be done in less than a 1 sec.  There is no requirement for set-up.  All  you need to do is to connect the Apple TV to your TV and power, and the icon for mirroring function will automatically shows up on your other Apple devices.  I've had a lot of fun with the mirroring function with my cat, he truly believes now that there is a huge rat lives behind the TV screen because I played a lot of rat videos on my huge Sony TV through mirroring function via my Mac Air.If you have a PC and no Mac, then there is no question about it that you should choose anything but Apple TV.  I have a Windows 7 PC laptop, and I can stream movies to my Sony Blue-ray through the windows media sharing client function.  However, it does take a bit of effort and time to set up.  Not nearly as easy as Apple TV Home Sharing.  So, if you have a Mac and you want to stream movies or videos, then your best bet is Apple TV.  However, if you have a PC and want to stream videos, then you must use Blue-ray or other Windows compatible devices, unless you have purchase movies directly on iTune, then it is ok.Finally, Apple TV does not take blue-ray disk or any other DVD.  Also, to my surprise, if you try to play DVD through Airplay, it won't work either.  So, if you play DVD every now and then, then Blue-Ray is your best bet.After testing out both the blue-ray and Apple TV, I think these two devices aim at different population and they do several different things as mentioned above.  I am glad I got both and I do NOT feel like they are redundant technology.

iPhones and three of these Apple TVs.  We've migrated from Windows over the last few years, much to the chagrin of my Microsoft employed brother in law and are more than satisfied with the move.The home sharing feature allows us to access all of our photos and videos which are stored on our Apple Time Capsule.  We can also throw content to the big flat screen from our various hand held devices and of course, access our music library and the various on demand services that Apple TV does support including Netflix and Apple's own iTunes store.  These functions were the reason I purchased this since we already had a Roku which provided the same content and then some including Amazon Prime and is also a great device.The remote control is a work of minimalist art which allows you to navigate the user interface with just a few buttons.  This matches the design of the unit itself which is a simple hockey puck sized black plastic box whose light weight allows for it to be mounted discretely with just some adhesive backed velcro.  You can also use your iPhone as a back up remote once you install the app.Over all, this is a great unit to add to an Apple household due to its ability to let you share content, access your iTunes library, etc..  However, if this isn’t important to you a Roku might serve you better.  Google also has a new streaming device on the market that certainly warrants a look.
summary: No Amazon Prime but other than that, excellent

reviewText: I purchased this to "mirror" web movies/shows from my ipad, specifically from Amazon Prime.  It does not support Amazon's streaming protocol.  I sent it back since it was an expensive device to show photos or play itunes content.

Received this $100 gift as a Christmas present.  We planned to use it primarily for Netflix.  Loved it when it worked, however, after only 3 months of use it keeps losing the signal.  I've spend HOURS online with tech support to no avail.  The last time I called they told me it would be $20 a phone call from now on.  I threw this piece of garbage in the trash and bought a blue ray player which works well.

The Good:Most features work as described.  Home sharing was incredibly easy to set up.  Now I can stream movies from my itunes library to the TV, which is my favorite feature.The Bad:I have been plagued by a buffering issue.  When streaming video from Netflix or my itunes account, the video freezes.  I have numerous devices that stream over my network only the AppleTV experiences this problem.  My home network is quite robust and I have tested for network interference as well.  The issue persists even after all other network devices are shutdown.
summary: Good, but buffering issue prevents better review

reviewText: This is a good product. It goes without saying as it is branded as "Apple". But as far as utility goes, It is good for those who have an ipad, iphones and other apple products and its just useful for mirroring your other apple devices on your TV. Other than this, i think its not that much useful. There are other products worth 30$ approx available. I have an apple macbook pro but to be able to use apple tv airplay with pro, i am being told to pay $20 to update my OS version to be able to use apple tv which i think is ripping money off you and making you stick to only one brand.
