I like to be a free bird and I do not think I liked it when it comes to utility but the quality of the product is very good and it does the few jobs its suppose to do preety well.
summary: Good for those who have apple branded other products

reviewText: Until about a month ago, I totally enjoyed this product, but recently Amazon made it so that the Amazon Instant Video app on my iPad does not transmit video to it.  I suppose this is an effort to sell their Roku product, but it's disappointing since that was one of the main reason I bought it.

We own MacBooks, iPods, iPhones, and iPads all in a variety of versions.  The apple tv is my LEAST liked product. It is always losing connection with my wireless whereas nothing else seems to have that trouble. I have a roku as well and it NEVER loses connection to my wireless. The graphics on the screen, like the iTunes screen are fantastic I will say.  But that is a minor point. Also, the remote is so tiny. I've already lost one remote. I had to go purchase another one and they are pricey!  We are huge Apple fans, but I am just disappointed with the apple tv.

I thought I would get more use out of it but since it doesn't let you view Amazon prime its a waste of money to me. I enjoy Amazon prime movies a lot and iTunes just doesn't cut it for me and it cost more to view thru iTunes.

Not going to get into Apple vs Roku fight as I have both on my TV.This is because though they overlap, example with Netflix, they have different lineups and functionalities.Taken together, both give me a wide variety of TV shows, easily.So yes, when I want to stream my iTunes collection to my TV, I use this.If I want movies from Amazon, that are not on Netflix, I  use Roku.One thing the Apple TV supports is a full wireless keyboard via Bluetooth.So I use this with the Apple Wireless keyboard so I can access YouTube easier when I'm in the mood to search for old TV, for an old TV show themed party...."The Fugitive or The a Untouchables " anybody?If you want to nit pick over this sub hundred dollar item, vs the Roku sub hundred dollar  item, go ahead if you have the time.For me, I'm going to sit back and enjoy the wide variety of streaming content I can get with both.There are more important things to obsess about in life.Bottom line, it works as advertised, if you have other Apple  products, it complements them.
summary: I love it especially after the recent software upgrade.

reviewText: Purchased the Apple TV primarily for streaming my movie collection onto my HDTV without needing to convert file formats for iTunes/Home Sharing or AirPlay.What an enormous letdown. AirPlay Mirroring simply did not work for me despite countless hours of online research and having conversations with users at Apple's discussion forum and the Mac Rumors forum.The Beamer app (a 3rd party app) worked for standard definition content but not for HD movies. The company that makes Beamer blames my relatively new MacBook Air. I seriously doubt that.User interface is ugly too. Just a bunch of tiles that are clunky to navigate.The one time I rented an HD movie from iTunes via the Apple TV it would not start playing for at least an hour. I thought movies were supposed to start after a few minutes. I'd rather rent from my cable company via VOD.I'm sure the Apple TV is great for many others. I'm a huge Apple fan myself. But for my needs it was a disaster. Probably going to purchase a WD TV Live Media Player at some point.UPDATE: Okay, I'm updating my review because I found two apps (Infuse Pro and Air Video HD) that essentially allow me to AirPlay natively (not AirPlay Mirror) video files to my TV via my Apple TV.This is huge for me. It's essentially the only reason I bought my Apple TV to begin with. It really sucks though that AirPlay Mirroring really isn't an option for many of us when it comes to streaming our video content. I feel like Apple is really not being honest on that front.Also the interface as of the summer of 2014 for the Apple TV is simply gross. Even if you can delete channels it's still ugly and a poor user interface. I suspect this Apple TV will get a software facelift come fall of 2014.So yeah, thank you Infuse Pro and Air Video HD for allowing me to use this device as I intended to all along.

This not as great as other Apple products. I LOVE my macbook but HATE this box. It is SO annoying that my iTunes has to be on for Apple TV to run it (i.e my laptop has to be on the entire time we are watching TV, & when my daughter closes the screen her show stops & chaos ensues). Before this we had a Roku (that we moved upstairs to the bedroom TV) that could stream Amazon prime videos, connect to HBO & showtime GO, Facebook, and gives you endless options of channels to purchase. Apple TV gives you NO options other than the standard few things it comes with (I hope you like Youtube, Netflix & Hulu bc that's it!). Also, most annoying, the remote control is freaking TINY. I mean, MINISCULE. I get it Apple, you are sleek & cool, but it is really NOT cool when I can't find the damn thing every morning when my kid wants to watch tv. Seriously, this remote is about 3/4" inch wide by 4" long by 1/16" thick. It's about as easy to find as a toothpick in the couch. I moved the Roku box back downstairs & now use both intermittently. If my husband didn't love Apple so much I would send this back for sure.
summary: Unless everything you ever watch is on iTunes, get Roku instead. TINY REMOTE

reviewText: I bought my Apple tv in April of 2012 and wasn't exactly blown away by the capabilities of the device.  It plays any expensive movies you buy on Itunes.  You can play your iphone music on it.  It will also play netflix.  It's only in the past year or so that it does anything else and it still seems limited compared to the Roku 3.It worked fine for the most part during the past 2 years, but there were several times when it needed to be rebooted because it wouldn't show up in the list for Airplay on my other idevices.  About a month ago it simply lost connection to the wifi.  I rebooted and it reconnected - for about 10 minutes.  I did a reset and it reconnected for 10 minutes.  I then did a restore with the latest software and it reconnected for about an hour.  I then plugged it into the ethernet cable and it reconnected for 10 minutes.  The thing is basically a hocky puck now.I went out and bought a Roku 3 and this thing is amazing.  I can use Plex along with the other items that Apple tv allows (Netflix, Hulu, HBOgo).  Plex alone makes this thing worth it.  It also allows you to play your iphone music on the device, but it will not play any purchased movies from your iphone on the Roku - that is the only downside I have come across.  But who really does that anyway?  It also has a wifi connected remote that allows you to put the Roku completely out of sight.  And the Roku 3 is very fast - I have never noticed any lag moving through the interface.If you are on the fence about the 2 devices, do yourself a favor and get the Roku 3 - it is much more capable.
summary: Wifi died after 2 years of use

reviewText: I don't have a HDMI cable. After so many days of waiting it to arrive, only to find out that I can do nothing with it without a HDMI cable which is not even included. That's so disappointing. I decided to return it.
summary: It doesn't come with a HDMI cable. That's ridiculous

reviewText: I spent countless hours converting all my music and DVDs to Apple TV and it worked great at the beginning. Now, as many users experienced, every time I turn on the Apple TV it says I didn't enabled home sharing. I have to go back to my computer, turn it off, turn it back on and half of the time it doesn't work. I tried everything recommended by Apple including restoring factory settings but its a mess. Weird it worked so great for the first few months and now, without changing anything, it fails all the time. Very dissapointed.February 2012 update: Bumping to 3 stars as the problem with home sharing has gone away. I still wish the UI was better at discovering movie or music info, managing folders, or rendering closer to the original.

This is the third Apple TV that I have purchased as it is the easiest way to provide the Netflix experience to our TV's without the expense of true high end cable TV contracts.  A true bonus is the use of AirPlay via multiple apple OS devices we have in our house.  A BIG ease of use factor is the iCloud offerings of  our music and movies.  Gone are the boxes and DVDs.  The new Apple TV has a noticeable improvement on my large screen Panasonic TV.  The new upgrade to the software is so easy to use.  If you own an iPhone or iPad, be sure to download the free Remote app to control the Apple TV.  Highly recommend this!!

Very disappointed in the product, and plan to return it immediately.  It's a great concept, poorly engineered and supported.  Really, this review is not just a review of the AppleTV alone, but also the iTunes home sharing concept, which the AppleTV is very dependent on and is essentially worthless without.Home sharing itself is very quirky, with all kinds of little issues which prevent it from being totally reliable or really easy to deal with.  In spite of Apples normal intuitive user interfaces, the design of home sharing is clunky, poorly executed, and terribly supported.  In this particular case, one of the issues is that many many people (unfortunately including myself) discover some sort of application defect whereby after 5-15 minutes of use, iTunes/Home Sharing kills the host PCs wireless interface.  Keep in mind that this is on multiple test units, on multiple wireless networks, using multiple operating systems and multiple routers.  It is quite consistent.  Even on Apples forums (and many others) people have been unsuccessful in determining what factors lead to this to isolate root cause.  In my case, this is supposed to be a "convenience" item, and I've wasted more time than it's worth trying to deal with it, so I'm done.  I've attempted multiple times to engage Apple, however those efforts have been frustrating and totally unsuccessful.In particular, this makes it even worse as Apple TV is so restrictive as to what you can actually play through it.  Most of us already can stream netflix (if we wanted to) and a myriad of other sources.  The idea was to be able to stream video content from iTunes, and unfortunately, this device is simply ineffective.I did give it 2 stars instead of on, because if you put the host PC on a wired network, it seems to alleviate the issue.  And before anyone comments to the contrary, this is the absolute ONLY function that the networks and hosts in question have any issue with.  These networks and devices routinely move FAR more content and FAR larger data sets/files via wireless than anything iTunes does.  The issue is clearly, concretely, Apple TV and iTunes - period.  Even Apple support finally acknowledged that.Some people are able to get this working well - nobody seems to understand why some have issues and others don't.  My advice is to really test the heck out of it if you're going to try it, so you can make sure you can return within the window.  Further, make sure you understand exactly what it does because it's much more narrowly focused than you might think in terms of capability.

I have had numerous other Apple products- iPods, iPads, iMacs, iPhones, etc.  This is by far the worst Apple product I have ever used.  Why?  Simple: Airplay, which was my only reason for purchasing, doesn't work reliably.I purchased this because I wanted to be able to listen to music from a computer or mobile device through my stereo system. I have tried the device with numerous TV's and receivers and consistently get HDCP connection errors.  It is rare that I can get it to play more than a single song before wireless drops or there is an HDCP problem.

I received this as a second-hand gift.  I won't buy another Apple product and this one reminds me why. Unlike my Roku, this one will not allow me to watch content from Amazon Prime instant streaming.  Netflix works OK, but if I want to purchase and view content from iTunes, I have to download the entire content before it will play.  Usually, this means downloading today to watch tomorrow.  One movie that my sister purchased, we were never even able to watch.  Apple's restrictive policies are keeping me away for good.

This supposedly new APPLE TV arrived with a persons user name and premium subscription movie service programmed on it that belonged to someone else. Running back and forth to the computer to program it is a hassle too.Dissatisfied in Utah

I truly wish I could love this product.  I use it more than the average person because I do not have cable or even antenna tv by choice.  i have a very large tv screen but use it for movies and apple tv only.  i have to say up front that if you don't have netflix and don't want it, DO NOT buy this thing.  this little black box should basically be called the Apple Netflix Client or something.  beyond that you have the ability to watch youtube videos (duh, even your phone does that at lightning speeds now - but then.... it can also bring you netflix now)  and if you have like an NHL or NBA account where you pay those buffoons more money to watch a sport, you can, idk, watch them on this thing.what i wrote this review to complain about is the very thing this little box should be best at, but in fact it sucks at the most.  Connecting with your Mac computer and playing movies/music/podcasts, etc.  it can do this, let's be clear.  that is a major selling point for this item.  it extends MOST (but not all) of your Mac's content to your tv.  cool.  but only so cool if it works 40% of the time.  basically, if you're on your computer and you add ANYTHING to your itunes library and then want to view it on your tv, the apple tv will tell you you have to turn on home sharing on your itunes.  even when it is clearly still on.  this stupid little box will insult your intelligence and get you so frustrated you will be at an apple store within a few days, and they will tell you there is absolutely zilcho they can do for you.  added: it will even do this if you so happen to turn on your Mac while the apple tv was already turned on.  good luck.  you have to engage your mac products in a certain order i guess, or suffer the consequences.this product has connectivity issues - and the ONLY way to resolve these issues is to yank that power cord out from the back and start fresh (allowing it to restart which takes just about as long to boot up as my 27 inch IMac WTF) just to be able to view a newly added item from your itunes list.  CRAP.  not like Apple's reputation at all.  really, really, crappy.  you'd think if it had these issues one of the abundant "geniuses" at this company would have thought to make it at least easier to restart somehow.  how about a switch?  you know, like most electronics?  oh, what's that?  apple isn't most electronics companies?  I DONT CARE I SHOULDN"T HAVE TO SUFFER FOR YOUR STYLISH REPUTATION.  make your product work, then make it look all space-age and overly simplistic.  make it reliably connect to your OTHER products, like you say it does, then sell me glamor and chic.now, you may be reading this and thinking, well, mine doesn't act this way.  i don't care.  the fact is, mine certainly does, and since the people at apple tell me it isn't defective and therefore won't assist me in solving the problem, i have only one way to view this product, and that is as a totally functioning, totally ill-designed piece of garbage.  i think they care very little how this product performs because they know that at 100$ it's almost the cheapest thing you can even buy in an istore, so it's going to sell no matter what.thanks.
summary: apple fell far from the tree here

reviewText: After a few months, my unit stopped communicating with the wifi router. After a quick search, it appears to be a common problem. Not ready for prime time. Sigh...

Many of the more recent reviews of Apple TV have been negative, very negative. Mine must be also. I have an older model that works perfectly. The one I just bought did not. (To be totally upfront this was a refurbished model that I was assured by Apple would function exactly as a new one would. So I trust that the fact that it was refurbished was not the problem.) My internet connection was working as it should. My home network was also working as it should. I was able to watch Netflix movies with no problem - no streaming issues, no buffering issues, no issues at all!! But, the airplay feature on the Apple TV was not working properly. I was not able to airplay movies from my iPad or computers to the Apple TV, even after spending a lot of time on the phone with Apple Care. The people I spoke to on the phone could not easily solve the issue. Their only thing they could recommend was to "restore" the Apple TV. This took over an hour and required re-doing three sets on User IDs and passwords - a frustrating process with Apple TV. Unfortunately, it didn't resolve the issue. It actually made it worse! I called back, explained the situation, and was transferred to another person. He had no answers but would check with someone else for assistance. We were cut off. He didn't call back even though he had my number. I waited 10-15 minutes and called back myself. I eventually got transferred to someone who would try to get me to the previous tech person. In a short time, we got cut off again. There was no call back. There was no email sent to me as a follow-up.This morning, I brought the Apple TV to a local Apple Store to return it. My home network was working as it should. Any software issues were addressed with the "restore". Therefore, it seemed rather logical that the problem was a hardware issue. BUT, at the store there was no offer to exchange my unit for a new one to see if that was, in fact, the problem. I would have appreciated the offer and given the new unit a try. As it was, I left the store with a refund, but no Apple TV, and a somewhat negative feeling about Apple, in general. Apple Care offered no solution. Neither did the store. I am very disappointed in Apple customer service. I expect more from them. And, just for the record, I have been purchasing Apple products for 30 years. My first computer was an Apple IIe.It seems there is a problem with the newer versions of the Apple TV, problems that Apple hasn't addressed. Purchasing one at this point is a gamble. Maybe it will work, maybe it won't. I would recommend waiting for any purchase until there is a solution and the product is reliable.

Well - what to say about the Apple TV3?It doesn't do anything.  Can't stream from Amazon, can't stream from a media server (without iTunes), can't play music without iTunes.Can't watch internet TV without a subscription.Can't jailbreak it to make it useful.There's a whole lot of "cant's" and for the life of me, can't find any "can's."Unless you bleed apple blood, don't waste your time or money on this.  A complete waste; and cannot for the life of me figure out why anyone would want or use this little black box.

Airplay quit working after working flawlessly for last year.  I have followed directions on numerous websites using all advice found.  Restarted a million times.  All updates are current.  Of course apple blames problem on my router. (everyone always uses the "it's your router"  response.  It worked on this router for the last year.  I have tried 3 other wireless routers and have plugged in directly.  I believe it has to do with apples updates.  Seems like all there products get messed up after updates.  Be very careful buying this product, seems I am not the only one with this problem.  Very expensive just to quit working.  It is a neat product if you can get it to work, unfortunately like all apple products they only work for so long and updates will not allow you to do what they have always done.

So you have a iPhone or iPad or Mac laptop and you want to stream to your TV?Try buying a cable for ten bucks and plugging it into the HDMI port.All AppleTV does is act like one, and wants you to start subscribing to more services and stream those.  You could get those on most of those subs on your device and just hit play and watch it on your tv.This is just a device for Apple to make money on continuous content purchasing and frankly, if I want to buy content I don't need this thing.  Returned.
summary: Waste of money; Device wants more money.

reviewText: I am a loyal Apple product guy, but this product does not live up to their usual standards.  Every time I use it, I need to do a full system 'Reset All Settings' in order to get Netflix to work.  Every day I use it requires the following steps:1) Selecting a language2) Selecting the wireless network3) Type WEP password4) Type netflix id5) Type netflix passwordIn addition if you want to use any of the apple related content (itunes, etc) there are some additional steps:6) Type Apple ID7) Typing Apple PasswordIt may not seem like a lot, but it definitely far from user friendly and becomes annoying very quickly.  Previously I had a Vizio Blu Ray player that was unusable.  It was unresponsive to the remote and extremely slow in general.  There would be up to a 1 minute lag between pushing a button and having the DVD player respond.Next step will be to try a Roku, it can't be any worse.
summary: Requires Constant Resetting - Not Up to Apple's Standards

reviewText: Ok first let me say, I am a big fan of apple, I have the I-mac, I have the i-phone I am in it to win it.  But negotiating this thing feels like, like, when I use my husbands PC! nothing makes sense, movement wise, when interacting with netfix, my old roku is way better, and  I can't get my I-mac, OMG from WAY BACK in 2010 ...a whole year and a half old...to display on the screen.  When I purchase things from the I-tunes, even though I have gone through the long slow process of enabling home sharing, for some reason the apple still does not compute!  WTF apple?! how am I supposed to convert my husband to your product?! AND the netflix dosen't even stream in Hi def! BOO!...back to roku...or my husband's 2007 pc laptop connected to the samsung ( too bad apple didn't make a drive for my laptop)

Since I purchase a lot of content outside of Itunes this box is very redundant and loses a lot of functionality. It aggrivates me that Apple always tries to force you to buy everything from them or else you cannot use the content you have purchased. The box is easy to set up and will take you approximately 10 minutes if you have a basic understanding of your network and encryption.Overall I am not impressed. I spend more time looking for the 3 inch remote then I do actually watching programs, and all of the programs I have to buy, only to sit though commercial after commercial. Why do I have to pay for the shows, then I cannot fast forward though commercials? Let me get this straight, I pay for the show, and then Apple gets paid again by forcing me to sit though commercials? Um...no.If you have a gaming system like Playstation or Xbox you do not need this as it has the same content but with limited ability to use. I do not intend to keep paying for programs so that I can watch commericals all day.If you have nothing else than this might be alright for your purposes, however I am sorry that I bought this device.
summary: Redundant and not worth the hassle of paying for programs and getting commericals

reviewText: Makes no sense.  I have subscriptions to Hulu, Netflix, and Amazon.  I have an ipad, Macbook, and iphone.  I love Amazon instant movie...yet Apple decides to be re tards about it and not add this app.  I'm selling it and going to ROKU.  Why does Apple have to be so lame????  Wish I would have researched before I bought.My fault.  You can learn from my mistake.***********UPDATE**************  - I didn't understand how the product worked.  Duh.  If you have a MAC, or Ipad or Ipod, or Iphone, you can use whatever you're doing on on that device to put upon your tv.  I did not understand that...I just thought you had to use the apps on the Apple TV.My fault.  So I updated my review to 5 stars.  It's awesome.  Getting another.

If you want to be able to watch movies and TV programs off the internet on your TV set you have two options.The first is that you can buy an Apple device and get iTunes content. That'll work if you live in a country that Apple acknowledges.  Except that you won't be able to do very much with the content, like play it on some other media player software (one that allows you to copy your DVDs as well, for example) or copy it to another device to watch outside your home, or migrate it to a new device if you need to.  It'll also cost you a surprising amount of money, but in the event the download is corrupted or deletes itself there is no support. And it will take a while for new content to become available, and your friends in one country might be able to watch something that you in your country can't.The second is that you get it off a pirate web site in which case it doesn't matter where you are or what hardware or software you are using, won't cost you anything, will let you decide how and where to watch it, will be available more quickly and will look just the same on the screen. And you won't have to provide your complete biographical profile or create an account.My point is that Apple (and other content providers- don't even get me started about Sony) make it so hard to get content legitimately without offering a single advantage. They all go on about how piracy is stealing, well that is their entire business plan! In order to avoid "stealing" we should choose to watch overpriced content with strictly limited functionality- or not watch it at all because we're in the wrong country. In other words we have a moral obligation to jump through hoops and provide them with big profits.That doesn't sound right to me, huge corporations taking the moral high ground. I could have gone along with paying the money if the functionality and availability was the same as it is for illegal downloads. In fact for a long time I only downloaded illegal copies after I'd bought the legitimate Apple TV content. I thought that was a morally acceptable alternative. But now I live outside of the US and the content just isn't available so I can't do that anymore.  I can walk into any store in the US and buy a book, CD or DVD and take it to another country, but I can't download that same movie from that country. Since Apple (and the other content providers) have made it impossible for me to buy from them, how can I be costing them anything if I download it illegally?So now here's what I do: I download the content illegally and watch it however and wherever I choose, then I either send the author/ director money by paypal or through their website, or I make a donation to a charity on their behalf and mail them the receipt and a note explaining it and pointing out how absurd and outdated business models are stifling their industry. I pay them half what Apple charges, which is more than they would get otherwise, and Apple gets nothing.

AirPlay is the reason I bought 2 of them. I stream my photo album, music and videos from my iPad, iPhone and laptop through Apple TV to my receiver and it looks and sounds great. Very very cool feature and makes it stand out from Roku and other players. There is a app for Apple TV called Remote that's free lets you control your Apple TV with swipe gestures.

Apple TV is great for Netflix and quickly ordering movies from Apple.  For those unfamiliar with Netflix, the interface actually does vary between devices you use to access the service.  Apple TV provides the best Netflix interface I have seen  The Radio app is also a great feature, 100's of stations to choose from.  The photo streaming is nice if you have flikr or icloud, but is clunkier than you would expect to set up.  By far the best feature if you have apple devices like iPad, iPhone, etc.  is the ability to show audio, video or mirror your screen from your device.  Lots of fun to surf Youtube videos this way.  if you get tired of the radio stations, it is straightforward to stream something like Pandora from your iPod, just one button to push.  The only problem is poor quality, especially the wifi connection.  The support forums are full of horror stories with this device.  My wifi just stopped working after 9 months.  Trying to get warranty service for it, but its really a poor showing from Apple.  If you buy it, cross your fingers and hope for the best--and maybe spring for the extended support contract for this one.  Usually that's a money loser, but it will likely pay off for this product.
summary: Nice when it works but poor quality from Apple

reviewText: I'm sure I am going to take a lot of flack for saying this since a lot of people love everything apple does, but this Apple TV is just OK.  Before you start clicking the unhelpful button let me set things up for you a bit.  I have a fair sized library of music but not many movies in my iTunes.  On the other hand, I have a lot of my personal DVD's burned to my windows server and can watch them throughout the house on other devices such as my Google TV blu-ray player, or my 1st generation Roku XS,Owning all 3 devices, here is a quick list of plus and minusesAppleTV+Netflix+AirPlay from iPad (Air Parrot from MacBook Pro)+YouTube (Kinda)+Cool screensaver and remote content+iTunes protected content+Podcast support+Hulu-No Amazon VOD-No DLNA support-No USB Drive supportRoku+Amazon VOD+Netflix+USB Drive Support+Hulu+Plex (All my movies available from my server in a great UI)+YouTube-No DLNA-No DRM Movies-1st gen can be slowGoogle TV+Netflix+BluRay+Native DLNA Support+USB Drive Support+Great Remote-No Hulu-No Itunes DRM SupportIf you could combine all 3 of these products you would have one great device (A Jailbroken ATV2 is almost perfect).  For me though being an Amazon Prime member, and a Hulu+ member the fact that Apple TV doesn't Support either is a pain.Another thing that is a bummer in the iTunes ecosystem is the price.  A quick glance at Amazon vs iTunes on a movie like The Avengers shows that iTunes rental costs $1 more, and to buy the movie costs an additional $5 over Amazon.  I can't figure out why that is.Basically, if you are heavily invested in Apple and iTunes you will love this device.  It has the slickest UI and operated Apple smooth.  If you are not, I think there are better options.
summary: Like every other streaming solution, good but not great. (vs Google TV vs Roku)

reviewText: Pros: It is crystal clear compared to my BluRay player's similar apps (Netflix, Hulu, etc)Cons: The remote is difficult to use for typing.For the most part, I am very pleased with this product. It is far better than the apps I was using on my BluRay player to accomplish the same things. The addition of the Watch ESPN app is a great feature that I can't wait to use this football season (requires a subscription).The one thing I don't like is typing with the tiny remote control. My email address is rather long, as are all my passwords, making signing in to apps very cumbersome with this remote. The navigation is slightly difficult with the toggle button on the remote (my large thumb sometimes activates the wrong side of the switch). But this is definitely not a deal breaker for me. It would be great if I could connect my wireless keyboard to it for sign in purposes and searching.Overall, I very highly recommend this product. It's another example of a long line of Apple products that are clearly ahead of the game.
summary: Overall very pleased with this product

reviewText: The main reason I purchased the AppleTV was for the Airplay feature. Shipping with AmazonPrime is always fast so I received my product on time. Installation for the AppleTV to my Home Theater System was very simple. Make sure you have an HDMI cable ready because this does not come with one. (I didn't have an extra one so I had to buy another HDMI cable online which prolonged my AppleTV usage for another 2 days) The Airplay feature works amazingly great! I'm very surprised of how easy it was to actually use this feature. At first, I thought I had to install a software, but once the AppleTV was connected, there was an Airplay icon that appeared on my Macbook that I click and BAM! Your desktop is on TV. Resolution on the TV is very nice and it also sends the audio to the TV. I connected this to my Home Theater System so the audio is surround sound as well.The only complaint that I have is when you're connecting to the Wifi, it does not scan for available networks; therefore, you can't click on the available SSID and connect to it. You physically have to type the EXACT SSID. This took me a while because I didn't capitalize a letter, forgot to put a symbol, didn't put correct spacing...etcAlso, I already had the remote control for my macbook pro (Remote configured to my macbook) so I decided to use this remote instead of the one that came with it.Since the remote is already synced with my Macbook, every time use the remote to go through the AppleTV, this would also increase/decrease the volume for my Macbook which was a bit annoying.Photo stream works just as great as it did with my iphone and Macbook. (It does take a while to load all the photo stream photo's onto the Apple TV)The movies that were being offered through the AppleTV were a bit pricey, but that's what Redbox is for.My only intensions of using the AppleTV is solely for Airplay. Once you set everything up, usage is simple and I'm glad that I purchased the AppleTV.Another fine product from Apple!
The new version of Apple TV does not have volume control and doesn't work if you are using an amp to send the signal throughout your house.

Apple arguably has the best-developed video ecosystem in the business. Their video rental selection is top-notch, you usually get iTunes digital copies with the Blu-ray combo packs you can buy, a good (not great) selection of TV shows are available, there's tons of great free content (news, vlogs, etc.) via Video Podcasts and Apple's developed a way to stream what's on your iPad 2/3 or iPhone 4S screen to an Apple TV via a technology called "AirPlay".I personally have around 100 iTunes movies and it's great to be able to sync them to my iPhone/iPad for my kids to watch when we're out and about, then come home and stream them to my TV with a push of a button.As you'd expect with Apple, the interface is top-tier. Sure every Blu-ray player and game system out there nowadays has YouTube, but usually the interfaces are clunky enough that you rarely use the feature. Apple TV's Netflix interface is also my favorite of the plethora of streaming devices I tried!If you have a lot of iTunes video, a Netflix subscription, rent a lot of movies (but hate driving or waiting for the mail), or watch any Video Podcasts, it's surely worth dropping $99 on this puppy.However, it's not perfect. First, while this is the first "1080p" Apple TV, you shouldn't expect Blu-ray quality (as is the case with any current media streamer). Blu-rays pump out up to 40 Mbps of data to your TV, while Apple suggests you have an 8Mbps connection for their "1080p" content. Thus, while the resolution is technically full HD, movies have to be so compressed that they lose a bit of color depth and sound quality in order to make streaming over the internet practical: in short, this device is about convenience more than quality.Also, while Apple TV supports a lot of content that no other media streamer can (iTunes video in particular), there are some services notably absent from the selection. For example, there's no Hulu+ and no way to download it since the Apple TV has no App Store.The good news is that you can partially overcome this limitation with the video mirroring "AirPlay" feature of iPad 2/3 or iPhone 4S. The bad news with these devices is that the experience is suboptimal. Using Hulu+ as the example, the first thing you'll notice is that the aspect ratio of the iPad and an HDTV is different, so you get black bars on the sides. The picture is also relatively low quality, but it does the job.Nevertheless, since a lot of Blu-ray players offer Hulu+ and even apps, it puts the Apple TV at somewhat of a functional disadvantage in some respects.However, even with its limitations the reality remains that Apple TV is my go-to device for Netflix, YouTube, movie rentals, iTunes streaming, video podcasts and even Flickr slideshows of family photos. What the Apple TV offers, it offers better than any other device I've tried.
summary: A Must-Have For Video Buffs Living In the Apple Ecosystem, But It Comes With Caveats

reviewText: I love the Apple TV. Works seamlessly with my iPhone 4GS and iPad for mirroring. Great if you have some friends over and want to throw up a YouTube video for everyone to watch. We even take turns with our phones controlling which video we're all watching. Kind of a fun party game.Also have Netflix and NHL GameCenter subscriptions, and very satisfied with both of them on Apple TV. For the NHL games, especially, you can go back and watch EVERY game throughout the entire season--both home and away broadcasts. Amazing, and no need to DVR 3-hour games anymore. As far as Netflix is concerned, I can't imagine going back to watching on my laptop now that I have this hooked up to my TV.**The only con/drawback I would say is that mirroring and video playback via your iPhone/iPod/iPad does depend on the strength of your WiFi network. I actually relocated my router closer to the entertainment room where my Apple TV is hooked up so that I can optimize the connection. Other than that, this is a great product and very satisfied with it.
summary: Probably the best $100 I ever spent

reviewText: Just wanted to let pc buyers interested in purchasing apple tv know that you can stream wirelessly from itunes, but you will not be able to mirror your pc. Only ios devices can.

Man I love this thing.  Not sure why I waited so long to grab one but lately I've been getting serious about ridding of cable.  Sure the AppleTV has its limitations, but that's really only because of limited deals with TV providers.  This will improve over time but the state of this device is still amazing.If you have an iPhone/iPad, using Airplay to stream your content to the TV is just amazing.  From songs to podcasts to Youtube movies, it's awesome.  Using iPhone as the remote control for this device is the only way to go as far as I am concerned as my fat fingers kept hitting the middle button on the included remote by accident.Personally I am using Hulu plus, Netflix and I got a flat OTA antenna for the free OTA HD channels.  Homesharing - playing songs from your iTunes from your PCs - very nice.And for the guys out there I am just gonna say it - you can stream free porn onto your TV via Apple TV.  Come on you know you're going to do it.  Wife and kids is away shopping and guess what, you have the house all to yourself.  You gotta keep the pipes clean and keeping prime can prevent prostate cancer.  The porn streaming works really well but get ready with emergency volume control.  Come on you're going to do it - you know I'm right.
summary: Like tech stuff?  Just get one...

reviewText: I was waiting for this 1080p release for over 6 months and finally arrived 3 days back. I already have PS3, WD Live Plus and few china made PMPs. I was eyeing on this because of its AirPlay, Youtube HD streaming, Mountain Lion's Airplay and possibly also for XMBC.Pros:o Simple to setupo remote is intuitiveo Can use "Remote" app to control and to type texto Low power consumption compared to my PS3Cons:o The usual complaint - less contents.o compared to PS3 Netflix - same HD content* Not impressed with the clarity* Streaming is not smooth and buffers often(I have connected my ATV3, hardwired to ~30Mbps internet connection)o Airplay videos from iPhone 4S (using n) takes forever to play* Looks like it downloads the entire video and plays.Still keeping the box, hopefully I can airplay using my iMac once Mountain Lion is released and possibly I should be able to install XMBC ;)Overall I am ok with this box.
summary: May be I am expecting too much...

reviewText: This a wonderful device for people who want to find themselves constantly:- reconnecting to their non-apple wifi,- inputting their credit card numbers over and over again- resetting device for it to function- and generally getting frustrated after a long day because they cannot watch content they paid for.Truly a splendid device for going ballistically mental.simply get a Roku and save your nerves.

Very tightly controlled by Apple, like all Apple products. Will only play iTunes stuff from iTunes store or from a few services like Netflix. Just not enough. Get a WD TV box and you can then play your own video files from anywhere on your network plus all the services on the internet.
When straeming, it drops the connection on a regular basis. Not very useful when you are trying to watch something and it drops out every 30 minutes.

Awful, awful, awful!  Not what I've come to expect from Apple.  I bought this to replace my 1st generation Apple TV which had an internal hard drive that died.  Big mistake.  I gave it a noble try, but ended up returning this brick.  Since the newer Apple TV doesn't have any onboard storage, or any way to connect external storage, a computer has to be running any time you want to watch your own content (or listen to your own content without paying for an Apple cloud subscription).  "Okay," I thought, "it's the latest and greatest, and I have an old Mac mini I can leave running all the time."  Big mistake.  Not only was it a pain to set up, it kept losing its connection to the computer ON A HARD-WIRED, GIGABIT NETWORK!!!  Every time it would drop, I'd have to go to the computer and re-start iTunes, and point iTunes back to the photos folder I wanted to display on the Apple TV.  If that wasn't bad enough, the Apple TV has such a small photo cache that the screen saver displays the same few photos over and over.  It isn't even smart enough to go and grab a handful of different photos from the folder that iTunes is pointed to.  Instead of enjoying my media I spent all my time being an IT tech.  Not fun.  Buy a WD TV, but not this!

Very easy to use as most Apple products, but of course limited to a few sources of content. But I'd be fine if that were the only issue, as we know Apple likes to choose for us. What I find annoying are the constant reboots I need so that remote would resume working. It also has a big buffering issue with Netflix to the point that it sometimes becomes unpleasant to use (something that doesn't happen when watching on PC or iPad). Would give it a 5 star if it worked as advertised.
summary: Great idea, but plagued by glitches

reviewText: I pre-ordered this from Apple the first day I could and received it today (the 15'th) a day before you can actually pick it up in the Apple store. I upgraded from a first-gen Apple TV.So is it worth the upgrade?1080P is nice. REALLY nice. The new menu seems to work well too. But honestly, its just the 1080p thats the upgrade, but it's well worth it. You can see the difference easily and Airplay for me is a little bonus. If you sell your second generation Apple Tv on amazon it'll cost you about $30 to upgrade, if you sell your first gen (160gb) it could cost you as little as $6 for full high definition, and considering that 720P HD and 1080P HD on iTunes cost the same, if you settle for less it just seems like your getting ripped off.EDIT/UPDATE:As of July 31 2012 the Apple TV now comes with Hulu Plus, making it (for me) the perfect product.AirPlay has worked fantastically for months, I'm extremely happy with iTunes movie/tv show selection and the quality of it all as been amazing.

Maybe I should have thought this out more. I added this to my cart on a whim when getting the new iPad. It really is a sleek little device but it just doesn't meet my needs. Just to make sure you don't fall in the same boat, here are a couple things to consider before buying -Navigation -  Navigation works fine, but typing does not. Using a four direction pointer to type will quickly frustrate you and bring back nightmares of trying to type your name on the high scores list of an old Nintendo. Just because this has the best navigation on the market doesn't mean it is good. Call me when this gets Siri voice input. In the mean time, I'll hook up my mac mini and use a keyboard.Content - Awesome if you use Netflix and iTunes. Not so great if you use Amazon Prime and streaming music services like MOG or Spotify. I know I can airplay music from my iPad or computer, and that really is awesome, but even more awesome is having that content natively supported. Roku has it, Apple TV doesn't.I have huge respect for apple devices and have always been satisfied in the past, but this one just doesn't do it for me. Maybe once Mountain Lion comes out with its native support for Airplay of your Mac screen I'll give this another look. Until then, I'm returning it for a Roku.---April 2012 Update---Just to follow up, I never did get the Roku. As commenters pointed out, it just has different shortcomings. I've had my mac mini hooked up to the TV since though, and I'm pretty convinced this is the best "interactive-TV" option on the market right now. Here's to hoping Steve Jobs "finally cracked it" for the next ATV. If so I'll be first in line.
summary: Once the "I have a new Apple toy" euphoria wears off I realize...this really isn't that great

reviewText: I normally expect Apple products to be high quality but my Apple TV didn't cut it. I have had it for 1 year and 5 days and it no longer works (the warranty is one year). I started buffering for long periods during play on occasion a few months ago but I thought it was just temporary issues with the streaming. But now I can hardly get through 15 minutes without this. It also will freeze completely. I have to completely reset the device and then it is OK for a few hours then it starts again. I mostly use it for Netflix but I do also use trailers and podcasts.I have this on a high-end HD TV and picture quality is great. As usual, Apple has made the presentation slick and the hardware itself is attractive. I also have a Roku on another TV and it never has any problems. I have to replace the Apple TV and it will be with a Roku. If you must buy an Apple TV, you better get the 2-year warranty if you want something you can use for a while. My advice: buy a Roku!

When I first got it, I immediately ran into the HDCP required for playback error. I managed to get around this by doing the (what should be unnecessary) song and dance of unplugging and turning things off and on, and it worked for a while. I then made the mistake of updating the software. Now, all I get is the HDCP error. So I put it aside for a bit, and recently bought a brand new plasma tv. Boom, same HDCP error. If you're looking to watch netflix, I'd much rather recommend a hdmi cord and connect your laptop to it. Apple clearly doesn't care about quality anymore, or even delivering a product that actually works.
summary: Garbage device, do not waste your money. HDCP errors render it useless.

reviewText: The only reason we purchased Apple TV was to view our Amazon Prime content. Come to find out the Amazon Prime Instant Video app disables Airplay on Apple TV. So, that means you cannot watch Amazon Prime videos on your television when playing them from your iPhone. You know Apple, we would have bought content from you (new releases, etc). Now I am just one peeved customer who will not be shouting "Apple TV" from the mountain tops.We will be returning this unit.
summary: Very Disappointed: Does Not Work With Amazon Prime Videos

reviewText: I bought this product based on my longtime experience with Apple. What a disappointment! I find that now Apple has reverted to the "black box" practice: no product data or support. To be specific, I found out that this device works only with some of the expensive newer Apple products. I have an early 2009 Macbook 13". Fast and reliable. Well, it is NOT compatible with the ATV 3. Neither is my iPhone 4. I understand that its predecessor, the ATV2 was "jail breaked" and works fine with most of the older models. It seems to me, that Apple re-engineered the ATV3 (that Amazon labels "the newest version") to force customers to buy the latest products and prevent any modification to the device that could result in better use for the customer. Interestingly, the ATV2, now discontinued, now can be bought used at better that $400.00!What as scam. No more Apple of any kind for me.

My son bought me this for Xmas. The first thing struck me was 'Apple asks people to buy this to buy their stuff?' It is like having to pay for the shopping cart to shop at Walmart! How clever! Some people, for example the ones camp out on the street to buy new Apple stuff, may be so ensnared by the name Apple to do that. But as far as this product is concerned the king is naked. Also, the 'airplay' is poor at best and I have a robust WiFi, which I juggled in many different ways to deal with spotty performance to no avail. For this money one should simply buy a DVD with a built-in WiFi and access Netflx, Hulu, etc. I should know some about this stuff; I am in IT business, 25 yrs in all.

I have the Roku Player latest generation / Most expensive and while it is very good another 5 Star Item I find I prefer this for several reasons.1. This device has a manual sleep feature.2. This device does not get hot like the Roku Does.3. The quality of the streaming from Apple is second very good.4. The Quality of streaming from Netflix is Superb better than my Roku.5.Access to my Itunes purchases over the years very nice.6.Air Play and screen Mirroring very cool anything I can play on my laptop including instructional videos and materials for school can be placed on the big Screen.7. Built in UTube player very useful when looking things up.Things I do not like about the Apple T.V.1. The remote Apple likes to rely on style but it has exceeded itself this time Blending Style and being cheap have created a tiny  unwelcome easy to loose remote for the Device. The buttons are recessed into a thin aluminum rectangular remote that fits a child's hand better than an adults.2. Supply your own HDMI Cable one does not come with the Apple T.V.Things I like about the Roku Player better1. The remote is simply better it has earphone Jacks that allow you to watch T.V. without disturbing others.2. The remote feels like you actually have something in your hand and is great for playing Angry Birds with on the Roku.3. Unlike the cheapskates at Apple Roku includes not only earphones for it's remote but an HDMI Cable.4. Amazon Prime Video streaming. I guess greedy Apple does not want competition playing over their device. Too bad Apple tries to charge for everything I can only surmise that the only reason Netflix is available through it is that they knew they had nothing to offer without it.Overall worth purchasing.
summary: As a Roku owner I prefer this device

reviewText: Other than that, it's yet another device you can watch Netflix on, or rent movies with. Having an MCE PC, and the fact that this thing has no additional apps, I feel like I wasted a hundred bucks.It's a great idea, but very weak execution. Needs apps, sorely.
summary: Works well for ios mirroring.........and that's really the extent of its value.

reviewText: Pros:1. Design, no external power adapter (more than five star)2. very easy and simple to use3. Fits well with iCloud/iTunes ecosystemCons:1. Optical audio should have been hybrid 3.5mm/optical2. Missing bluetooth3. Amazon VOD is missing4. Limited software capabilities.

we really like the apple tv.  the air play mirroring is amazing.  we are using airparrot to use air play for our mac book pro and of course our ipod and ipad has air play.  with our mac book we can watch hulu plus and amazon prime.  we love the podcasts and netflix content on the box.  the interface is great.  I cant wait to see where this goes.  I would love for some more apps on here.  apple tv is great if you have apple devices for the air play alone.  The only reason i am not giving this 5 stars is because of the fact you dont have hulu plus and amazon prime but with air parrot for your mac book you can!try the trial if you have a mac[...]we love it!

They say 51% of U.S. households own an apple product well I personally own 2 macbooks, an iPhone, and iPod, soon to be delivered iPad (didn't quite make the 2days shipping), and Apple TV (HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT). I purchased the Apple TV thinking I could Mirror my Macbook Pro to my Samsung HDTV and use it to watch AMAZON Prime. Being a huge fan of Amazon, I dumped Netflix and bought Apple TV hoping to stream Amazon Prime videos to my HDTV through Apple TV (Herein lies the disappointment). Like all other apple products it is a beautiful product with inherent simplicity but it looses big time by not having an Amazon App or interent browser capabilities that I have seen. Maybe Apple designed it this way so that you would be influenced to buy an iPad for the mirroring capabilities. I don't know if Amazon can get Apple to get in line with this Apple TV snafu but I sure hope something resolves. For now I have a $99 swell looking device that neither connects to Hulu nor Amazon Prime but will play iTunes across my TV speakers. Whooptie Doo! Can I get a refund? I had planned to use Apple TV to seamlessly push histological slides and xrays through homesharing to devices for better studying and finishing my work. I'm sorry Amazon I should have bought the ROKU when you made it an awesome gold box deal for me :(. And I'm cutting you slack on the two day shipping because I ordered very late last saturday night. It was Easter Holiday Sunday. I'm just hoping that my other order get's in before clinic tomorrow so I can try my hand at patient charting on the iPad.

With Roku and blu ray players featuring not only Netflix but Amazon and tons of rich content, why would anyone one want Apple TV?  Ignorance of other alternatives, I suppose. Get a Roku or net-equipped TV or player and enjoy the content without Apple's proprietary junk.
summary: Limited, redundant and for apple fanboys only

reviewText: There's something you must known about AppleTV before purchasing that may change your mind.#1 - You CANNOT play your library of movies and tv shows WITHOUT a computer or ipad/iphone device being ON and STREAMING directly to Apple TV. What?! It's true. If you have a library of movies and tv episodes you'd like to watch on Apple TV -- well, you'd have to power on your machine, then stream it to Apple TV. You can't just turn on Apple TV and watch a movie or tv episode you've purchased outside of Apple TV. Any purchases you make ON and THROUGH Apple TV, you can watch without having a computer on, however.WHEN COMPARED TO ROKU -- Apple TV fails when compared to Amazon VOD, for example. On Amazon, whether you purchase on your PC or through the VOD channel on Roku, you can watch your content without a computer. Your library shows up on the Amazon VOD channel on Roku. No need to power on your PC or Mac then stream it to Roku.#2 - You CANNOT play iTunes U content WITHOUT first downloading it to your PC or mac/iphone/ipad, then converting it to a Podcast. What?! It's true. If you want to watch iTunes U content on your Apple TV, you first have to download it on your device, then change the video format. Then stream it, again.At this point you're wondering, what if i just turn on my PC or MAC, put in an HDMI cable and connect it to the tv? Hmm... should I pay $99 for that ability? Oh wait, it doesn't cost any money to do that already (provided you already have an HDMI cable).Hopefully the next gen of Apple TV fixes these problems.
summary: 2 Things You Can't Do on Apple TV that You Think You Can

reviewText: I have been a happy apple user for many years. However, this apple TV has changed all that. I have been on the phone with apple for more than 3 hours, my phone company for 2, a family tech wiz for 1, not including my own time on the internet. It still won't join my network. I have been able to download and re install the soft ware on this product, but it refuses to join for anything else. Apple finally decided that it was due to WEP password on my airports. I changed everything to WPA as they requested. Still doesn't work. I opened the ports, still doesn't work. Shared the connection from my mac, still won't work. My brand new mac joins with no issues at all. Apple is refusing to replace. Very disappointed in this"new" un-customer friendly apple. I will return this product and purchase a ROKU which is almost 50% cheaper and reviews say does twice as much.

I am on my third Apple TV.  Apple 1st gen was OK.  2nd ten ATV has died after 15 months.  No recourse.  I bought a new one APT 2nd gen and it died after 16 moths.  I own a lot of Apple products, but I have never experienced such poor quality before.  Is it just me ???
I cancelled my cable TV and bought an Apple TV. The best deal I made in recent times. Saved a lot of money and improved the quality of information I have access to.

The original Apple TV had a built-in hard drive.  You would buy media on your computer, and send it to the Apple TV as you would your iPod, iPhone, or iPad (other devices with hard drives) but wirelessly via your home Wi-Fi network.  Now, the Apple TV streams.  There's just enough storage on the device to hold buffer data, but the concept is that it streams the data.  Which means, the computer has to be on, and iTunes has to be open.  I think.  At least, that's the only way it works for me.  If the Internet goes down (problem with the ISP, cable cut, bad storm, whatever), you will have a tough time watching anything via the Apple TV.With the original Apple TV, after sending media to the device, I could turn off the computer, disconnect from the Internet, and watch and listen to whatever resided on the Apple TV's hard drive.  It'd be nice if Apple could bring back the previous capabilities while retaining the current form-factor and other improvements of the current Apple TV.  For now, as long as the Internet is up, and my computer doesn't crash, it works great.
summary: Sometimes a pain, but mostly great

reviewText: I have had my apple tv since July/2010.  Here are the things I like-dislike about it:LIKE:- setup is easy- Video resolution is good(we are still on the 720p box)- the remote is built well and has been dropped a LOT without issues.- AirPlay is a nice feature- different options to play movies, I.E. from my computer, netflix etcDISLIKE:- apple movie rentals are TOO expensive.  A B movie from 1985 should not cost $4.99.  A good example is "re-animator".  Some use the excuse of "well it's just convienent to rent from home blah blah".  Say what you want, but the prices are TOO high and keep customers like myself from renting.  Here is a tip to apple:  If you rent movies at .99 cents(older movies) and I rent 5 a week, that's $4.95.  Now if you keep the prices of those same movies at $4.99 EACH, I personally will not rent anything.  I am also betting a LOT of other customers don't rent because of the same issue.  So you either keep prices the way they are and get ZERO or lower them and get more rentals.  Why would I "buy" a movie on there?  Its not a tangible object like real blueray or DVDs.- Netflix - even though it's a separate company, they are attached in apple tv.  I spent over 3 months last year trying to resolve a buffering issue with them.  My cable company pointed the finger at Netflix and vice versa.  Some changes were finally made(they never told me what) and it got better.  BUT..... If I play Netflix from my iPad or Mac, I never get buffer issues.  This lead me to believe the apple tv was giving problems.-  HDCP error -  boy this is annoying.  You go to watch a movie and 4 seconds later it freezes.  A minute later the infamous "HDCP" error pops up which makes you reboot apple tv.  I have followed all the suggestions to resolve the issue and still get this error about 2-3 times a week.- TV shows on apple tv - $2.99 a episode?  Yep you read that right, they are $2.99 for ONE 47 minute episode.  I cancelled my cable tv in June 2011 and got a antenna. Now I get 24 HD channels for free.  I don't get discovery channel, or AMC but the savings alone make up for it(was paying $165 a month for cable & Internet), now it's down to $60).- I tunes festival - I'm not sure how that option showed up because it just appeared one day without updates.  Kinda boring.- Hulu plus -  if you have a Netflix subscription, don't bother with Hulu.  Netflix(dare I say it) has a better selection.  We tried Hulu for 4 days and most of the selections were boring or not worth watching.  There was also a HUGE selection of Korean movies.  I personally don't speak Korean, so they are worthless to me.- YouTube is what it is.... Plays videos from YT.- the other options are really boring unless your into basketball or hockey.  And even then, you have to have subscriptions to both.  Can we say nickel and diming here......With the way companies break everything up and "give you more options" these days, what it really means is "we are going to charge everything we can for EACH item".  Again, see my "nickel and diming" comment above.My wife and I are currently looking for a Internet ready TV so we can get rid of the apple TV box.  It's quite sad because we moved ALL of our computers(4 total) from PC to Mac in mid 2010.  Being really happy with the move, we figured apple tv would be awesome.  Needless to say, it's mediocre at best.And don't get me started on the horrible podcast or radio options.......  One word for them:  CRAP!!!!
It constantly looses connection to WIFI. The most frustrating thing Apple has ever made. The old one worked flawlessly. I hate this thing.

Things are not quite as they seem. If WiFi service in the dorm is through a "captive network" (ie, one requiring authentication before letting a user onto the internet), Apple TV does NOT work (ie, it won't sync with iTunes, and your computer will not recognize the device). Apple tech support says that Apple TV won't work with a captive network, and that I should buy a router and set up my own wireless network in the room--the school, however, won't allow me to do this. Come on, Apple! You had to know that this would be problem! Apple TV should come with a big black-box warning that it may not work in dorm rooms! How about a little truth in advertising! Right now, my Apple TV is just a nice shiny black paperweight

You say you game, watch Netflix, and surf the web all at the same time? Your connection still won't be fast enough to load a movie in less than an hour. AirPlay is extremely finicky, sometimes works and a lot of the time doesn't. Not sure why. Everything on this works differently as well. I can listen to music from my library in the background while wading through other menus,  but not podcasts. For podcasts you must not dare press a button or playback stops. Umm, okay... Go with a device that supports Amazon Instant so that you're actually able to start a movie in less than the movie's playing time. This is an embarrassing device not worth your time or the premium you're paying for it.

I own a iPhone,my wife owns an iPhone, we have a Mac, an iPad and until recently an apple tv. The trouble with it is it simply doesn't register with the afore mentioned line up. It's as if it was designed by another company and sold by apple. The thing is clunky, looses connection, and if you wish too mirror, you'll wish you hadn't. Games lag, web pages lag, and the channel inventory is second to all. The only saving grace was apples WONDERFUL customer service. They promptly apologized and refunded me. I am now the proud owner of a WD TV live hub and though it suffers a slew of hiccups it does what the apple tv does and so much more. Too bad apple. Oh well, even Ty Cobb struck out every now and then.

Let me preface this by saying I'm a huge apple fan. I own multiple Apple devices. I was really excited to receive and try out the new revisions of the AppleTV3.Unfortunately, it did NOT work with my TV. I was using a 2012 model Toshiba 50L5200U. This TV is HDCP compliant (according to the TVs manual) but I could not get any video out signal from the AppleTV.I tried 3 different HDMI cables, in the 3 different HDMI ports on the TV in various combinations and it would not detect a video out signal from the ATV. Audio however, worked (using optical audio out).I have read various forums saying AppleTV3 will not product a video out signal if the TV is non-HDCP compliant but this model is. I have heard people reporting similar issues after updating to the newATV firmware. Ive since returned this unit for a refund and will go with a Roku3. Highly disappointing that it would not work as I've always associated Apple products with reliability.

I have a love/hate relationship with Apple, but I just hate this thing. My feelings would be different if there was a Jailbreak for it (coming soon) and if in that Jailbreak I could access more things. What's the problem? NO APPS! Do you use Amazon to watch movies? Well, you can't on Apple TV. Do you watch cable shows on Xfinity? Can't do that on Apple TV. What about HBO GO? Nope! All you get for streaming is Netflix, other then Hulu which is crap. I am not even able to use Air Play and watch these apps on my iPad through Apple TV. What's the point of a set top box without useable apps? What's the point of Air Play if I cannot watch these apps that are on my Ipad? I have the first generation Roku and it is far more capable then this thing. If you own or have ever used a Roku then don't even think about this device. Apple needs to open up the source code on this and let people create apps for it. Some of the previous mentioned apps are an issue with them and Apple not seeing eye to eye, but as the customer that is not my problem.

Most of the reviews here are spot on - unless you already own Apple equipment, buy a Roku instead...I found a major bug which is not yet resolved as of this writing.  At first startup, or if the Apple TV ever gets unplugged or there is a power failure, the Apple TV goes into an endless loop trying to set the date and time.  After searching the web, I learned that you need to use a secondary wifi source, such as your cell phone's hotspot, to connect to the Apple TV - this fixes the problem, and you can then go back and connect using your wireless router.Each time you have to reconnect to your router in this fashion, you then have to re-enter your router's password using the klunky Apple TV user interface.  Then you can finally use your Apple TV again.Until this odious bug is fixed, DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT.

I recently purchase an Apple TV, and I must say I am horribly disappointed by the experience.  This product absolutely does not live up to Apple standards.This feedback has been prompted by an increasingly frustrating series of experiences with my Apple TV.First, I was quite surprised to learn that I can not rent a movie on my computer and then stream it to my Apple TV.  I must rent it on my Apple TV or on my Mac.  This is just silly...I can stream a movie that I own from my computer to my Apple TV (a movie which is physically sitting on my computer and then streamed to my Apple TV) - BUT I can not stream a rented movie from my computer to my Apple TV (a movie that is, incidentally, ALSO physically sitting on my computer).  But I was willing to overlook this flaw...Next I was disappointed in what seems to me to be a rather clumsy interface.  It looks great, but I just found that several menu options were not in intuitive locations.  I was also willing to overlook this though.Next...I was disappointed in the performance of the iTunes photo streaming...I could not get the Apple TV to stream my entire library, apparently due to the size, yet I found no readily available guidance on how many photos I can expect the Apple TV to stream reliably.  It works as long as I select a limited number of events from my photo library.  Ok, a minor annoyance, but again I was willing to overlook this.But this next issue was the straw that broke the camel's back...I had several friends over to watch War Horse on Friday night (which I had to re-rent on the Apple TV once I discovered that I could not rent on my mac and subsequently transfer or stream it to the Apple TV).  I click play, excited to watch my first rental on the Apple TV.  I'm surprised to see it will take 1 hour and 40 minutes before we can watch the movie.  Dismissing it as an inaccurate estimate of the remaining time, I am hopeful after the estimated time fairly quickly drops to 36 minutes...still disappointing, but acceptable.So we switch my TV input to DVD and watch a short home video for about 25 minutes (while the Apple TV keeps downloading).  When we switch back to the Apple TV, it STILL says it will take 36 minutes, and then it jumps up to 51 minutes.  At this point, I unplug the Apple TV, switch to the free Amazon App that is in my Panasonic TV, and within 5 minutes we are watching the movie.  You can't blame it on network issues, since Amazon was able to stream it without a problem in less than 5 minutes under the same network conditions.This experience renders the Apple TV almost completely useless.  It is now reduced to a nice screen saver that shows SOME of my pictures, and a way to share my iPad screen without connecting a wire.  I'll be returning it, since $100 is too much to pay in my book for a snazzy screen saver and to save a cable connection.I hope Apple rectifies these issues at some point in the near future.  I really wanted to like this product.

I have an older Roku at home and bought an apple tv as I expected the same functionality as the old Roku along with the ability to control it with my iPad and iPhone. I was shocked although it will play Netflicks Apple has chosen not  not support Amazon instant video which is my personal favorite. I am not sure if they have excluded others but I immediately sent it back when I learned that. What was really frustrating was that the only was I learned this was by setting it up. I found nothing in the on line product specs or on the packaging that shared this lack of comparability . The documentation says it plays your favorites.

Lowered to 1 star, DONT BUY THIS PIECE OF CRAPAfter the latest SW upgrade, everything has problemsa) Watching iTUNE movie, failed in 10 mins, and did not show up in rentail queueb) Watching Netflix - a) movie pauses/exists about every 10-15 mins b) loses sound every 6 mins or so.So all in all - restart the movie about 12 times in a 2 hr period.This is Apple, not netflix, since other methods of streaming work fine.Piece of crap, do not buy the latest one.All the other problems below still existWhen microwave is switched on in the kitchen, apple tv connection drops. - another problem ......Lowered to 2 stars.Wifi conntection keeps dropping, and almost impossible to reconnect without restarting the apple tv box. The other end is fine (iphone, mac, pc, etc). The only way to reconnect is restart apple tv. Very poor wifi used the apple tv side.Sound is really choppy, if you are an audiophile, dont even bother with this device, it's no good for musicLowered to 3 stars.Apple TV often loses wifi connectivity. (This is apple tv, since my xbox does not)The remote interacts with macs and tv at the same time, which is annoyingMany apps - amazon, pandora etc, not available on Apple TV (although Pandora from iPhone can be played onto Apple tvOverall reducing to 3 stars.Bought this after reading all comparisons of Apple vs Roku. No regrets on my choice, but both have limitations hence 4 starsPrice - the two I looked at Apple vs Roku, price was only 1$ diff. (98 vs 99). Even that, a few days after I bought. Amazon dropped Apple to $92. So even better now.Apple streams most things through iTunesI got rid of my wires,/connections to my receiver for audio/video, now stream my musin through itunes. Sounds great.(Some of the wires I had, had noise introduced on them, from the laptop power supply, and I had this same problem on mac and PC.Movies too, I stream through Apple TV.Why 4 stars?Network connection - the Apple TV often drops the wifi connection and then comes back. Since my laptops never drop connection, the problem is with the apple tv box, not with my wifi.Other users have complained, and I can confirm too, that when the connection drops/comes back, several times, my laptops/iphones cannot detect the apple tv. Then you have to do all sorts of workaroundsa) Turn the wifi off/on on phone/laptop. This works most of the time.b) Restart either the apple tv or your phone/laptopMany movies do not work through iTunes, so I need to stream using Xbox/Media center PC/ Windows Media Player. This is inconvenientMany TV apps on Roku, very limited on Apple,and not free.
summary: DONT BUY THIS PIECE OF CRAP more problems wuth latest upgrade

reviewText: I bought this device to mirror my macbook pro on my Samsung hgtv. It doesn't work. After about 15 attempts to contact Apple about the situation, I'm giving up for the day. When I call them, their recording says to press "1" to speak to an advisor. Every time I did this, the phone just rang for several minutes and cut off. I expect more from Apple. I have an ipad and the latest Macbook Pro. These are expensive devices, and I expect better service for this kind of money. Right now, I'm extremely disappointed and I cannot recommend this device if you plan to mirror your macbook pro on your tv.

It is a typical Apple product (I own and have owned many Apple products: Iphone's (now using Iphone 5 and loving it), Ipod's, Apple laptop, Ipad's (when will it get a USB port?) and it looks and feels great.  Packaging is beautiful and the menus on TV are easy to use and easy to navigate.  I was about to absolutely love Apple TV, until I tried to get Netflix on it to work.  Got an error message on my TV about the HDCP security protocol.  Did some digging with Google and found pages and pages of people having problems with this.  Come to find out that most TV's built before 2010 do not have the HDCP protocol built-in.  The Apple TV did work great on my 2 newest TV's that both have Wifi and internet TV built-in already.  Kinda defeats the purpose of buying Apple TV doesn't it?  I wanted to use the Apple TV to get one of my TV's that did not have Internet built-in online.  Apple completely missed the mark here.  Who would buy an Apple TV device that only works with newer TV's, of which most already have Internet TV built-in.  Those TV's don't need Apple TV.  Naturally, I tried the Google Chromecast device and it worked great.  Within 2 minutes I had the Google device up and running.  Apple 0, Google 1.
summary: Don't waste your money, what a worthless product

reviewText: The Apple TV MD199LL/A seems to be a great little unit, but I'm posting to warn potential buyers who have older TVs.  My TV is a 62", rear-projection, DLP with a fantastic HD picture and HDMI inputs (Toshiba 62HMX84), but WHAT my TV is really doesn't matter.  What does matter is when it was manufactured.  When some of my content wouldn't play with an error about HDCP, I did some digging and found that in 2004, the HDCP standards (copy protection for HD shows/movies) were put in place (my TV is HD, but not HDCP compliant).When you use your AppleTV to play Netflix, Movie Previews, HD movies or TV you purchased from iTunes, they all require HDCP or you will get an error message on your screen and cannot watch them.  If you search for an answer, a lot of people will tell you to power off and power on both the AppleTV (or other HDMI device) and the TV...and this will work for some people, but if your TV is a little older, it may not be compatible at all.I didn't know I had this issue for a long time because my HD TiVO has component outputs that go to the TV (instead of HDMI) and Netflix will play fine HD from the TiVO, but this AppleTV has ONLY HDMI.I love the AppleTV and I'm going to keep it, but I can only play movies that are standard definition from iTunes, home-made movies or that I have ripped from DVD (removes copy protection as part of the process).  I will have to wait until I upgrade my TV to enjoy most of the other features of the AppleTV (renting movies from iTunes, Netflix, Previews, etc).  If you have nothing but time on your hands, I've also read that you can remove the protection from iTunes downloaded HD material, but you still can't get around the streaming content like Netflix or iTunes movie rental.
Apple TV is not compatible with Amazon.com. If you have Amazon Prime and hoping to stream movies from your iMac, iPad or iPhone to your TV you better look elsewhere. It doesn't work. Bummer.
This is cool if you have other iOS devices, if you don't own any other apple products, I'd suggest looking into a Roku box instead

I got this delivered about a week back.  Was very very easy to hook it up.  Only thing I thought was if they would include HDMI cable with the package, it would be more ready to use.  Love the fact that I just play things from my iPad/phone and they magically play on my TV.  I even was able to hook it up to my 5.1 Dolby Digital HTS.  It is awesome all the way.. at least now.  If I do see something later worth mentioning, I will update later again.

After trying both versions of the apple tv 2 and 3. I can say if you don't really need 1080p then there's really no need to get the newer version. Only a few sources at this point are 1080p. The iTunes store is the main source where you will greatly benefit from the 1080p. There are quite a few tv shows and movies in 1080p in the iTunes store to rent or buy. If your buying this device for 1080p on Netflix then there still aren't that many movies or tv shows. Also it's very hard to find which ones are 1080p.  Unlike the iTunes store which has icons for HD which means 720p and other icons for 1080p. The Netflix app only has icons for standard definition and HD. From my experience Netflix streaming had very bad picture quality.  The picture seemed to be artifacted and pixelated even with HD content. I had no issues with same content on my apple tv 2 or any of my other netlix devices on my 32mbps connection. I'm guessing that my apple tv 3 was defective as I haven't heard complaints of my issues. There are many threads on macrumor forums and apple discussions forums about the same issue. From my experience the picture quality was only bad on Netflix. Regardless of my issues I still feel the apple tv 3 is not up to par with other streaming devices.  Just about any streaming device (gaming consoles, blu ray players and media boxes) offer many more options in terms of services). In addition alot of them are cheaper or at the same price of the apple tv3. The newer apple tv does has have a faster processor and more RAM than the previous version. The only way to get apps and more streaming services on your apple tv 3 is to use air play with either an iPad , iPhone or iPod touch. At this point there is no jailbreak available on the apple tv 3. I didn't notice a difference in performance on the newer apple tv 3. Also I personally didn't notice a difference in picture quality between my apple tv 2 and 3.
